8-YVdmlffZBtTgCheDLJOw.text: My absolutely favourite restaurant. Table 26 and 14 are best spots in my opinion.Perfect place to celebrate. I love the smooth and cleaver customer service.Food is amazing and if you arrive early try "Catch me if you can" at the bar , great cocktail  to start with.

hGhYWmqkPKaQhYY7SjJcqw.text: This overall was a solid "OK" experience.  Very traditional steakhouse, but by UK standards probably above average.  We arrived about 20 minutes prior to reservation and were politely greeted at the door.  We were offered to have a drink at the bar while our table was made available.  I ordered a gin martini and my wife ordered a glass of champagne.  Pretty seamless, other than the Martini contained olives with pits... "Really?"We were shortly shown to our table.  I suppose we were allowed to peruse the menu for 3-5 mins and asked if we were ready to place our drink order/food order.  Since our drinks were still half full we asked for another few mins.Two mins later we were asked for our food order.  I don't know if this was just "really" attentive service or if the staff just wanted to prep for a short exit.  We decided quickly choosing the steak tartare and scallops.  I orders a ribeye medium rare and my wife ordered a fillet medium.  Keeping in mind that I made it a point to ask how their medium rare was which is described as red throughout.  I suggested to my wife that this is probably too rare for her.As our waitress disappeared and there was no offer to refill our drinks.  The starters arrived... No drinks... The starters were really great... No drinks.Waitress arrived about 10 mins later.  Re ordered drink.Main arrived 5 mins later.My ribeye was really nice, but not much better than I could make at home (Costco steaks are pretty good quality).  My wife's fillet was under cooked by medium standards (frustrating).  Polite enough she didn't ask that it be returned.Third round of drinks came promptly enough. Main finished and we ordered the sticky toffee pudding which was really nice.We ordered the beef dripping fries and the sprouts.  They were both "meh".As I said this is a solid steak house, but I wouldn't go gloating anything worldly about it.  If you have a craving for a steak then go for it.  If you are looking for a really first class meal that is above and beyond keep looking as London had better to offer.

TalY8NI0udP5SB4hr27fFQ.text: My wife and I are from Southern California and came here while traveling on our two year anniversary. IT WAS AMAZING!!! The ambiance was really nice with low lighting and candle lit tables and a retro Hollywood gastropub feel. The staff was so friendly and made our day so special. They sat us at a really nice corner table, gave us 2 free glasses of champagne, and when we ordered dessert they made it really nice! Not to mention the steak and food was fantastic. They have a very cool unique drink menu too. If you're in the area and looking for a nice steak house. This is your place!!

photos.caption: Photo of Hawksmoor Seven Dials - London, United Kingdom

YKsq-nvHrgRsuiQ8SCpX-A.text: Expensive but worth it when in London. Not the best Steak (ribeye) I've had but great experience with cool atmosphere.  It is loud which was fine for our family but if your looking for quiet might not be the best spot

CkC-yRMUq8LN5L_dRam7hQ.text: Expensive steaks. Well-priced Sunday roast. Tasty food all-round. Delightful sticky toffee pudding. Nice washrooms.

U0FsKexxT2b77uyAFAOFHA.text: Everything was amazing here from start to finish.  Hostess and bartenders were friendly.  Cocktails were delicious.  Great Sunday Roast.  Found the yorkshire pudding to be a bit overcooked and duck fat potatoes too hard. Otherwise a good experience.  I would return.

JCRoh18s05Kp-M03o9iP2Q.text: This is regarding a visit in July 2011 - I had high hopes for this restaurant.  I ended up being disappointed.  I had their burger, triple cooked chips, and bone marrow appetiser.  The burger was somewhat undercooked and I was not impressed by bun nor meat, the chips were so-so (and a let down after a week of frites in Amsterdam and Brussels), and the marrow was marrow like.  They have a wide range of juleps and mine was good but not memorable.  The restaurant itself was beautiful.  A rude woman stabbed my wife with her purse coming out of the lady's room and did not apologize.  We located a bandage within a few minutes at a pharmacy.

_mDfoYqi9Uag_dOyuq2hIg.text: Class, food, venue, cocktails.  Not sure what more to say but came here after hearing about their burgers.  Service is brilliant and they made sure we knew everything we needed to know about our food and drinks, while being attentive but not over bearing.  It has the feeling of an members club with the wood panelling and smart décor.  We had steak, burger and the chips which were out of this world.  Wanna go back for more and bigger steak now.

95jKwd_BKHBT7t3x5NKblg.text: We chose this restaurant based on other reviews and were not disappointed. It's an expensive, special-occasion place but well worth it ... and not a typical stuffy locale. The cocktails were unusual (and great) and both the filet and the surf and turf were just as good as expected. And don't forget the sticky date pudding sundae!

CnmfwaVzA8F6gso3pjL_RA.text: This is great fun and the food is good.  Starts with cool bar into a v cool large spacious basement restaurant.  Next its the steak list on the blackboards setting out the type and size available.  So been twice and had a porterhouse and a fillet.  Other reviews say steaks were over cooked but mine are always undercooked.  which is a pity as eveything else is v good.  So dont say medium rare say I want my steak to be red in the middle and hot.

KWFSleNMBEEECWn22qVn3g.text: We enjoyed the Hawksmoor on our visit to London recently. The chateaubriand was deliciously cooked and melted in our mouth. The fresh bread was also a treat. I enjoyed the cocktail menu. The service was "interesting". Our server let us sit for a good 1.5 hours before asking about our order. He did not approach us, he needed us to stop him when we wanted to order. A few other disappointments: It got VERY hot and VERY loud in the restaurant by the end of our Saturday night dinner. The sides were also not very good (we had the asparagus and beef dripped potatoes).

p75cbFluauRUNJ96mntvjQ.text: One of the greatest steaks ever. Go off peak hours for substantial discounts!

cIUXs1bd-9743LeJ_OGzDg.text: I was planning a trip to the UK with a friend who has never been outside the US and wanted the perfect Sunday Roast experience ...... And we got it at Hawkesmoor Seven Dials.  Great starting cocktails, delicious Sunday Roast beef cooked perfectly, and a great bottle of house red wine.  Service was great, restaurant charming....... Big win all the way around. I will definitely be back!

xAOg4CUlqgNcqJ6wh9tODA.text: I was underwhelmed by the steak here.  Perhaps I'm spoiled by the steaks I've had in NYC, but the steak here (I had the rib-eye medium rare) was nothing extraordinary. The belly ribs are quite average as well.h

9ElX2W3tNPwDULC7vxxw8A.text: Walking in to the place I was immediately impressed. Loved the huge black doors, dark wood, hidden coat closet, giant greenish wall to the right as you walk down the stairs, and the dim lighting and dark wood again throughout the restaurant. We had cocktails in the bar before and the bartenders/waitstaff were awesome! They had perfect recommendations and were so nice.* Wine list was affordable and impressive. I'm from California and it was nice to see some Californian wines on there!* Starters: Oysters with sausages (so tasty), salmon (yummy!), bone marrow (my absolute favourite... never had such a big portion!), and scallops (they were huge, but only 1 -- would have been nice to have one more)* I shared the porterhouse with a mate and all of it was incredible. Loved the sauces too. And the method of choosing your weight on the chalkboard was fun* Triple cooked chips were amazing (we ordered a second round) and ketchup was the best I've ever had* Mushrooms and spinach weren't that impressive, but not bad by any means* Salad with apples and cheese was lovely (probably some of the best apples I've ever had too!)* We shared two desserts and both were luscious. The lemon curd with shortbread and the chocolate puddings were the best way to finish it all off.

9E5vjhesCOE3ct9R9MaMIw.text: Great hamburgers of all kinds. Good drinks deals as well. Kinda empty the night we were there and the service was still slow.

vwnaD2jtBe9aEMPsrtaYig.text: Oh how it wishes it was an old traditional city eatery from the 19th century with its underground location, dark furniture and exposed brick work (for the real thing visit Gordon's wine bar in Charring Cross)...  The menu of steak and Lobster with a tiny number of other choices continues the dream, a cocktail list conjuring with very old cocktails, a wine list filled with tasty but weighty reds (with a surprisingly good and cheap house red ... a Tempranillo) and a dessert menu topped with one of the best sticky toffee puddings in London all make pretty clear the clientele this place is after ... Boys with money ... And funnily enough they are here in abundance but as there is so little bling none of them appear to have brought the pretty temp along with them ... In fact as the focus is so much on heavy rich food this seems to mainly bring the older better behaved city boys. Who are absolutely right as a better place to eat Ginger pig meat beautifully cooked with fine red wine and a dessert to thicken the arteries,  they and I have yet to find. It is all a very modern contrivance with as much authenticity and originality as  Lady Gaga performing 'Born this way'. A pleasure to eat at if you are willing to pay for it.

7er4WiFjpDHMDjGummY8Jg.text: One of the best steaks I've ever had. Very good service, they take the time to explain to you the difference between the cuts. Relaxed. Definitely worth trying. Think about reserving a couple of days (or weeks) ahead.

AYxeaoKEy6Ev-1LjPZPsDA.text: i had a wonderful night at Hawksmoor celebrating my birthday with my partner. this was our first time here and our waiter explained the menu and the cuts of beef to us in full details. i had a glass of Rioja with my ribeye cooked to medium and my partner had a fillet cooked to medium rare. all recommended by our waiter. the result: delicious and no complain at all! we also share half a lobster to start and we had beef dripping chips and cauliflower cheese as sides. for dessert, we shared a sticky toffee pudding with clotted cream and it was amazing!overall, the food and service were really good! the ambiance of the restaurant was nicely casual. there were quite a few business people having an after work drink but the staff is all dressed casually which i found it very relaxing.i will definitely come back!

UnaqMEl-T0g8vOe7oT7GdA.text: My Favorite Steak place in London was Hawksmoor at Seven Dials the this branch opened and not only did it have the fabulous steaks and service I had come to expect at Seven dials but the most amazing venue to add that has made this firmly my favorite steak restaurant in London.

4Q5fR9EBZHHlBF11KP6vEA.text: They say if you want the best steak, go to to Hawksmoor and they aren't wrong. I opted for a two course meal starting off with a Caesar salad, which was light and an perfectly portioned ready for the next meaty course which was steak and triple cooked chips. It delivered on all levels, nicely cooked and very tender and juicy. The chips were fluffy on the inside and crispy on the out, very reminiscent of Heston Blumenthal's  chips. The atmosphere was good and the service excellent. Overall, came out feeling happy and would definitely recommend this restaurant.

n6Elwthj5PjcZh4kXhHBQg.text: Hmm this is a difficult review to write as I don't really want to be a dissenting voice but my experience of Hawksmoor was very diasppointing. I ordered the set menu of the 250g ribeye and while I accept that this is one of the cheaper cuts its just wasn't up to the standards I was expecting. The meat did not have the depth of flavour I would expect it to have from good sourcing and ageing and it had quite an acrid almost burnt char. The home made ketchup did not have the right balance of vinegary and sweet and frankly Heinz is better. The side of roasted winter vegetables was just a few cheap bits of leeks, carrots and squash. The nicest bit of our meal was the cornflake sundae which was lovely but I don't think by itself would be enough to get me to return. I will be going to Goodman for my steak fix from now on.

Y5SDKKiEbsMytyUXEH7XLQ.text: If you like steak then this is the place to go. Outstanding quality and very friendly staff.

00pum40Zwqrlw841Wk20MA.text: nearly missed this place when looking for it as its recessed slightlya lovely little reception area where someone takes your coat.down the stairs to a large hall filled with high big tables in the middle with bar chairs and around the walls normal chairs and tables. we received a lovely welcome cocktail called a Hawksmoor Collins and after a while a few plates of bar food came around, i didnt unfortunatley get to try everything but what i did was ooooh soo very nice melt in the mouth lamb chops. There were porkbelly ribs, lobster rolls and i had my first oyster rather nice with the sauce. The cocktail menu is vast and i cant wait to go back and give as many as possible a shot. I was rather intrigued by a tobacco spray that they infuse over whisky cocktails.In all i had a great time and met some lovely fellow qypers and met a few of the qype organizers who are a very friendly bunch.

PSbXOhaq9BjMcCq_S8Wv6A.text: Always a pleasure to dine here. If its beef you fancy then this is the place to eat it in London. Wonderfully succulent burger, nice unpeeled potatoes used for the regular fries. The sticky toffee pudding is decadently divine! Yummy! (a star down for the little stone in the fries that almost broke my companion's tooth! to be fair, these things do happen and they dealt with it very well. They apologised and removed  the dessert from the bill).

WvdC67-2C2ifGFQDwqeaqg.text: Fantastic experience.  Steaks were excellent.  Interesting cocktail menu, good wines, friendly and attentive service, relaxed/ informal atmosphere.  I would recommend to anyone and cannot wait to go again.

yC9x7y8q8U7I6d5JxEDmPg.text: As an American, seeing Prime Rib on a menu sparks joy, enthusiasm and anticipation!  I guess, that British Prime Rib is different from American Prime Rib?  It was good...don't get me wrong but was not what I expected.  Service was great, sides were very nice (creamed spinach rocked) and wine was quite good too.  I guess I had my expectations set too high.  That being said, my colleague had the filet tail and she was so excited, let out a pitch only dogs could hear so for some, it really is heaven.

uJbGNxi5ldBtfelRjSwXYQ.text: I'm quite a few weeks late with this review, but life got in the way, and it's only now that I'm able to find some time to give the place the review it deserves. As with maggiebob, it's difficult for me to review the place based purely on the Qype event I attended. I mostly stayed at the bar area, as that's where all the action was at, so I didn't take a look at the dining area or kitchen. It's rather unlike the Spitalfields original in this respect. I certainly don't remember the bar having this much focus in the original. I'll agree with those who have compared it with Mad Men. I wouldn't be surprised if I walked in one fine afternoon and finding Don and Roger in a corner booth finishing up drinks! It can be a little hard to find the first time around. I was very confused by the large crowd hanging out in the alley and was worried there was a large queue to get into the restaurant before realising that they were all students hanging outside the Pineapple dance studio!

BJDqWm7vYQMBPvyhytG1Tw.text: It's hard for me to review Hawksmoor based on the Qype event I attended. I guess that means I'll have to make a repeat visit. But for now... It's not easy to find, tucked down a little side street in Covent Garden, but when you step inside Hawksmoor makes for a very sumptuous location. After checking your coat you descend to the bar which, as many people have described, wouldn't look out of place on Mad Men. We had a sample of the snacks menu, and everything we tried was top of it's class. The lamb was succulent and then lobster rolls are innovative. I think I'll have to return (with a full wallet) and sample the legendary steaks and extensive cocktail menu. I'll let you know if I do...

_RNr8mah5ZGiF83QWJ2Pdg.text: In my humble opinion this is probably the finest "steakhouse" in town. I was treated to dinner here on Saturday night, many thanks to B, and it was a wonderful experience in every respect. We kicked off our evening by grabbing a couple of stools at the bar and settled in for a cheeky cocktail. After a brief consultation with the very affable fella tending the bar I plumped for Shaky Pete's Ginger Beer while B had the Marmalade Cocktail, both from the Anti- Fogmatic section of the very extensive drinks menu. Excellent drinks, expertly made and lovingly presented, they certainly lifted the spirit and put us in the mood for the soon to come meat feast. At £7.50 a throw I thought this was pretty decent value given the location. After finishing our drinks we wandered through to the main room which is a very impressive "industrial" type space with exposed brickwork and blackboards dotted about showing the sharing cuts of meat and the weights that are available (be warned the smaller sizes where getting crossed of pretty quick). We kicked off by ordering up some sparkling water which B thought would help with the digestion of the beast we planned on devouring later. We also had a 500 ml flask of the Torrontes Finca La Linda, Luigi Bosca 2010 from the very well put together wine list which had plenty of decent bottles at under £25.00 (trust me for this kind of place in central London that's good pricing). This was a lovely fragrant floral white that went down well when paired with the oysters and the very tasty little beef sausages we shared as a starter. The main event was a 900g Porterhouse bad boy from Longhorn cattle reared in the lovely county of Yorkshire. To my mind the Porterhouse is probably the finest cut of beef and we ordered it medium rare as suggested by our lovely waitress Isabella. We paired this up with a 500ml flask of the Moulin Montarels Syrah 2008 which was nice easy drinking and went down very well. When the beast arrived it was a joy to behold, with a great looking char and vivid red flesh. The smell wafting up from serving dish was divine and I was sorely tempted to grab a chunk and eat the thing by hand. Going with the advice of Isabella we shared a portion of the Stilton Hollandaise which, as she suggested, was more than enough for two. On the side we had a portion of the beef dripping chips and also the triple cooked chips. These were pretty good but not quite the standard of chip that we had at "Dinner" a couple of weeks ago. However, that's a very minor quibble because the steak was fantastic and I would say it was the best I have ever had in London. If you are a fan of good steak I would recommend this place without hesitation; if you like the Gaucho chain I would definitely give Hawksmoor a try because in the steak world this is very near the top of the premier league. Somehow we still managed to squeeze a dessert in and we shared a portion of caramel ice cream and peanut butter shortbread which was very toothsome indeed. Thoroughly stuffed by this point we retired back to the bar, which was pretty heaving by now and was playing host to some very happy people. We had a couple of the Square Mile coffee martinis, a great way to get a caffeine and alcohol hit at the end of the meal, and spent a fun hour chatting and people watching. This is not a cheap night out by any means, but I think that overall you get pretty good value for your hard earned cash. You will be treated very well by the casually attired but very professional staff and any special requests you have regarding particular cuts of meat etc will be met if you let them know in advance. I'm already looking forward to going back to spend an evening in the bar and try one of the legendary Hawksmoor burgers.

oZK-_8U64L03bvHFrdjHtA.text: When Hawksmoore Seven Dials opened last year, it was really a struggle just to make reservations at a decent time. I finally managed to and have been back a few times ever since. I always love a good burger and was looking forward to this one upon hearing so much about it. The first time, my friend I both ordered the Hawksmoor burger with chips at £15. This is on the bar menu and not in the normal menu. It isn't a problem to request for the bar menu as I have done so many a time. The beauty of eating with a friend is the opportunity to try more stuff and it was a perfect arrangement of her ordering the triple cooked chips and me the chips with beef drippings. I also ordered my burger with Colston Bassett Stilton cheese and my friend the Ogleshield cheese. Our orders finally arrived. Apologies for the dark photos, it really was quite dark in there. The meat was utterly delicious! Juicy and bursting with flavour, you can definitely taste the difference when you get meat from a good farm and butcher. As much as I love my cheeses and don't have a problem with blue cheeses, the xxx got a bit too much for me. Maybe I'm not such a huge cheese lover after all. But if you are, you would love this. The burger with the Ogleshield cheese was easier on the palate. Creamy and melting into the meat, it was messily good. How were the chips? Crisp, crunchy and yummy. They were both good but my favourite has to be the triple fried chips. The kimchi burger on the menu has also piqued my interest and on my next return, it was kimchi burger time. I really don't know if this will actually work. I mean, kimchi is a Korean staple and is cabbage that is pickled and spicy with texture that is soggy and crunchy at the same time. When the kimchi burger arrived, you definitely know that it is kimchi. The smell is strong and hits you straightaway. To my surprise, it actually works in a strange kind of way. It may not be my favourite burger combination but I actually like this. I do applaud Hawksmoor for offering something so different and out there. There are a lot more protein options on the menu for those who don't like burgers. I should try them too the next time, if I can tear myself away from the Hawksmoor burger that is! I think the burgers and chops combo is great value and we should have more places like this which serve high quality food.

Y63OrzJhZRS3yatuHjf_Eg.text: Best steak in London, if not the world. The service is impeccable too, though in a friendly rather than stuffy way. Just a great atmosphere.

8FSRwICYskwbY4aLM8zP5A.text: The quality of the food and drink is sublime, the staff are friendly, helpful and relaxed, the ambience encourages gluttony and the Shake Pete cocktail knocked me for six (in a good way). On Mondays there's only a £5 corkage charge for wine, so it's possible to have a good night out here for around £30 each. What you really want to do, though, is wait for a special occasion and then fork out for as many steaks as you can to share between you. All of the sides are glorious. This is a seriously good establishment.

1wW0KU2XDt-IIlOFfX2Bsg.text: As other reviewers have said, The Hawksmoor Seven Dials is the perfect place for a steak lover. The wine list is extensive, the steaks fantastic, the service professional and desserts delicious. The sauces to accompany the steaks are quite large, probably enough for two to share if you're only getting standard size steaks and not one of their kilo steaks! My only comment, which is actually a compliment, is that the menu is mostly steak, and doesn't offer a lot of vegeatrians, but as long as you like steak, it doesn't matter!

DmoIL4XmmkFvrC-sGRM4_g.text: Good luck on finding the place (psst: it's pretty much opposite the famed Pineapple Dance Studios) - and once you do, you'll find a very imposing set of double doors. But get past those and there's a friendly host who offers to take your coat. Not many places do that these days for free, so there's a good start! Down the steps, and as someone else mentioned, it's a throwback to urbane 1950s New York, with a dark bar thronged with people supping cocktails and generally being fabulous. There's not really any such thing as a bad cocktail, but the Hawksmoor Julip was tastily bitter, and the Concealed Weapon certainly was. The bar snacks on offer are highly recommended - the lobster roll are oozing in gorgeousness and something slightly Oriental, while the lamb cutlets were very easy on the stomach. Of course, all it did was whet the appetite, and we'll have to come back one night for the steaks in the dining room, which looked opulent, spacious, gorgeous and well-lit. Definitely somewhere you'd take Christina Hendricks on a date swoon, and far more visually impressive than its predecessor.

clSa2MNJ-ylc-4FWKMHvaQ.text: What a beautiful restaurant! Luxurious wood paneling; soft warm lighting, delicious cocktails and melt-in-the-mouth food- this is going to be a very popular place if looking for quality around Covent Garden.The bar area, with zinc top and skilled barmen is a fantastic place to enjoy a cocktail- the mint julep with a sprig of lavender demonstrating that they give a twist to the many classics on offer. Of the food that we tried, a perfectly crisp-edged and pink-middled lamb chop that just melted and a perfectly done lamb rib that just dropped off the bone were the best offerings but it was all tremendously tasty!The dining area is plush, beautifully lit and comfortable. The service was friendly and informative. A genuine hit, and one I will be visiting again soon!

d4DJk3kqbP3hV1nJQt3KTw.text: Wandering down the stairs into the Hawksmoor, you might feel like you're in a library of some Oxford college. Dark wood lines the walls and floors, and tables are high recycled chemistry lab tops, lit with old Bankers' desk lamps.  The recycling bit even extends to the tiles, which are from old tube stations.BarChick felt like she should have been studying, so study the menu she did. Pete Jeary is the cocktail legend behind the menu here. He's nailed it, with all sorts of original drinks on offer: hit the Anti-Fogmatics if you're hung-over. Do NOT miss out on trying the Bloody Mary's. Pete recently won Tabasco's best Bloody Mary competition, so order some clams and he'll use the clam/bacon broth in your drink.  Now that's original.Hawksmoor probably serves the best steak in town, and you can order from the full restaurant menu in the bar.  The shorter snack menu is perfect though. BarChick loved the Kimchi burger, and everyone has to try a triple cooked chip or 3. If all this leaves you needing a pick me up then order in the Square Mile "martinis" - guaranteed to get you ready for a class at Pineapple Dance studios which is just around the corner!Perfect for a meat loving date, ideal for a client, and you can take BarChick there anytime!

cfmJuW-4iQ4YDEcpN56WFQ.text: Initially I thought the Hawksmoor bar looked like somewhere that should be showing American football games on giant TVs. It's all very leathery and dark, and weirdly American for somewhere that leathery and dark.I appreciated it an awful lot more on discovering these facts from the charming bar manager: - All the tiles on the bar's walls come from Tube stations- So does the flooring of lovely wooden panels (What the hell kind of Tube station is this?)- The table lights are old Bunsen burners- All the glasses and pretty silver drinks mats came from eBay and charity shops - That beautiful, huge wardrobe where you leave your coats is reclaimed as well. From where? I want an unfeasibly giant wardrobe too.- Not only do they make a beautiful, traditional Ramos Gin Fizz, but the barman added in a little nutmeg syrup to make it seasonal. How actually good is that? After filling our faces with samples from the bar menu which have been amply described by other Qypers (lamb - win, pork belly ribs - outrageous win, lobster roll - fine. But not for £20), Carla_s and I decided to sit at the bar, take advantage of un-fall-out-ofable seating and give the ridiculously boozy cocktail, Zombie, a try. I've only had one before, at the Notting Hill tiki bar, Trailer Happiness, but this one was delicious, fruity and left both of us screamingly tipsy. As a jaded cocktail bore, I was seriously thrilled by Hawksmoor's menu. There is almost nothing on there that I've seen before which makes a change, and some magnificently unusual ingredients. I picked the Johnny From London purely on the basis that it's last ingredient, Bouteille Call, reminded me of learning Beyoncé's Single Ladies dancing with my WI last month  great cocktail too. I'm saving my pennies to take my carnivorous hunk of a boyfriend here soon, I can't wait to try the dining room, but really, it's all about the super-talented bar staff and working our way through the menu.

isL6fU27hcyjYpw2sQ3hJA.text: The hawksmoor was one of many great meals we had while in London, the atmosphere is very cool, the colors are dark and the lighting is soft. We started our meal with a couple of beers, I was glad that we skipped appetizers, because our main plates were more than enough food. The meats were cooked just as ordered, I ordered my steak medium and my husband had his rare, i will say i have never seen a more rare steak, but apparently that's how he enjoys it.not only were we satisfied with the meats and the way they were cooked, but the fries are absolutely fabulous, they might be the best fries i've ever had. we also had a side gravy to deep our steak in, which was just the right touch.our server was very attentive and came to check on us periodically before, while and after our meal, she didn't miss a beat, a great meal with great service in a very comfortable atmosphere, I don't see why i wouldn't give the Hawksmoor five stars.

d4q_OMaDdddqfnL4yX8btQ.text: While it can be a bit of a search to find the Hawksmoor (we nearly walked past it!), once you enter you will be glad you made the trip. Nestled between the two Pineapple Dance Studio locations, its quiet exterior belies an incredibly posh interior. The bar area is very well appointed, and the bar itself is without a doubt the star attraction. As a pregnant lady, I was unable to take full advantage of the amazing concoctions surrounding me, but the virgin Mojito I had was just as lovingly created as my husband's grapefruit cocktail and 'concealed weapon' creation (it smelled DIVINE, by the way). The food was also stellar, with a lovely lamb rib, what looked like very yummy oysters, and a incredibly rich stuffed lobster roll. When I am no longer pregnant, I can't wait to take out a small loan (£16!) and try the 'zombie'. It looked... deliciously daunting. This is an establishment you should dress up for, and enjoy for a full evening. We can't wait for it to properly open so we can do the same.

BECZ4nkm1TdX7HQOrleWrA.text: Adding a review to the numerous superlative filled descriptions below seems almost pointless. However, our dinner was of such a high standard that I feel compelled to add to the sentiments expressed so far. It is, first and foremost, the best steak I have ever eaten. Rich, packed with flavour, but also perfectly cooked. We were a stag party of 13, with varying preferences, and every single steak was exactly as ordered without exception. A charred outside yielded to a pink, succulent inside and it was perfectly seasoned, not one of us reached for salt or pepper. In addition our sides and starters were similarly excellent, beef dripping chips gave me what can only be referred to as a 'mouthgasm'. My apologies now for anyone's dinner that this spoils! I should also make special mention of the service. We were in the private dining room and from beginning to end the service received was attentive and informed, but never fussy or obtrusive. In addition all the staff were lovely and blissfully unaffected by the many plaudits the restaurant has received. From the first bite to the last, our whole experience was flawless. Believe the hype, if you love steak, this place should be your Mecca.....

U10hSthIs5HEF-6kKjzUaA.text: Two words: lobster roll. Well, two words and a prepositional phrase: with bearnaise. I'm not a religious person, however this is the closest I've come to a religious experience in a long time. I generally feel lobster is one of the most overrated foods out there, but this is just that good. Of course, it's a mint: 25 pounds to be exact. Ouch. But throw in a bloody mary or two (not the gin one, though, it's a little odd) to soften the blow. Then prance on over to Bond Street and talk some of the boutique salespeople into letting you try on some hundred-thousand-pound watches--ya know, because you're an oil baron or something. Um, I'm not saying that's what we did or anything...

pKa6x-LfcECBuXUcQH7bvQ.text: Took my wife for a dinner here last Thursday as it was our 20th anniversary and I really wanted it to be an experience to remember and I couldn't think of a better place for that than Hawksmoor. Thanks to the friendly staff that attended to our every need, the delicious food and the superb atmosphere that night turned into one of the most memorable we've both ever had. I would like to express my gratitude for everything you had done in order to make our special evening even more special.

o6fzEs91E8ZSfmZ_jDmaiA.text: For photos see Greedy Diva @ greedydiva.blogspot.com/…  The new Hawksmoor, Seven Dials in Covent Garden is a shiny, brassy counterpart to its more pared back Shoreditch mothership. Located in the old Watney-Combe brewery, the front bar is dark, stylish and sophisticated. This is essentially a steak house (and a mighty fine one - I'll get to that later). But in the domain of proven bar man extraordinaire, Shaky Pete (who has moved over from the Shoreditch branch), we sip well made marmalade cocktails in martini glasses (£7.50) and some excellent lagers while making the most of Hawksmoor's superb bar menu. I've sung the praises of the extraordinary Hawksmoor burger before, its juicy, loosely packed meat laden with fatty marrow to give it extra richness. Rob orders it here and gives it the thumbs up - it looks every bit as good as those I've had at Shoreditch. Now, there's also a choice of the Burger Van Burger (a stripped down version of the classic Hawksmoor burger) or the Kimchi burger. For something different, I go for the latter and it's certainly an eyeful. The meat is fantastic (no surprise there), and it's huge. However, I'm not a massive fan of the kimchi (a Korean dish of fermented cabbage and spices). Rich and tangy, it's nice enough on its own - but I find it quite overpowering with the burger. If I'd never met the original Hawksmoor burger, I would be writing home about this one now - it's good. But we've met, I'm smitten and so it's the original burger all the way for me. The burgers come with a choice of thick, crunchy beef dripping chips (my choice - they're fantastic), triple cooked chips (both sorts of chips come with a gorgeous Stilton hollandaise) or a refreshing green salad. The latter may not sound as sexy but is terrific as far as greenery goes. (Burger and chips/salad is £15 - but, oh, it's worth it). TPG's lobster roll is a fine thing - generous pieces of sweet lobster are heaped into a long, warm, toasted brioche bun with garlic, hazelnut butter and mayo. Apparently, it's stuffed with a whole Dorset Blue. Strangely, there's a side of bearnaise which is excellent in its own right but I'm not sure what it's doing there with a lobster roll. The clincher is this baby is quite small for £25 and doesn't come with the side of chips or salad. In New York this week, I ate the lobster roll of my life (at Luke's Lobster, East Village), made with huge chunks of fresh lobster from a sustainable source in Maine - it cost me $14 (£8.73, review to follow). It may not be fair to make direct comparisons of two such different operations in entirely different continents, but it has to be said that the Hawksmoor lobster roll is hair raisingly expensive. But that's pretty much where my quibbles with anything about the Hawksmoor end. I also ate in the larger dining room during the soft opening period. Exposed brickwork and dark pillars give an industrial edge to the sleek room, which is perfectly conducive to the task at hand - consuming large quantities of tremendously good steak. All steaks are from Yorkshire Longhorns reared by The Ginger Pig and dry aged for at least 35 days. My preferred cut is the fatty bone-in prime rib (£6/100g), although they're out of that and the rib eye (400g, £25) by the time we order on the first night of the popular soft opening period. Our lovely waiter arranges for us to have a large chateaubriand for the same price (normally £12/100g). It's quite easily the tastiest chateaubriand I can remember, the dry ageing giving a great depth of meaty flavour. It's gorgeously tender and cooked to perfection on the Josper charcoal grill. There's a satisfying charred crust while the middle is lusciously pink and juicy. The delectable bone marrow gravy is our sauce of choice and we don't regret it. We share the excellent, crisp and fluffy beef dripping chips and a serve of creamed spinach (£4 each). TPG is tempted by the macaroni cheese, but we save it for next time. And now I have an admission to make. Before our ginormous steak, we also ate a serve of lamb chops. And it certainly taught me a lesson - just because you're out for steak, do NOT ignore the chops. They're grilled with a mint and caper salad which adds salty, zingy flavours to the deep, juicy meat (£10). Sublime. We also enjoyed the excellent prawn cocktail (£8.50). In the end, it's really hard to choose between dishes - so much appeals. The mini sticky toffee sundae (£4) is delicious with gloopy bits in the sauce at the bottom, although TPG's custard tart is a little bland (£6) - we regret not opting for the sticky toffee pudding which comes highly recommended. Your bill at the Hawksmoor will stack up - it's not cheap. Dinner for 2 with drinks is likely to cost around £100 (plus service). However, it's a joyous place to indulge in great quality meat with some classy cocktails on the side. If you haven't been already, add it to

ErUORXdHKBKJBmctfgZXiQ.text: A nice marriage between traditional and modern ambience, complements a wonderful meal. We enjoyed châteaubriand fillet tips (we recommend) and shared wonderful Stilton hollandaise and a bone marrow gravy. If you get there by 630 enjoy the express menu - both excellent and affordable. The sticky toffee putting is both sweet and savory and contrasted nicely with a clotted cream. The service was excellent.

Dgp5P4fgtwiWV3Q5C7HYZQ.text: Hawksmoor have outdone themselves here with what is, quite frankly, one of the best bars-cum-restaurants I've visited in London full stop. The branch near Liverpool Street is great in nearly every sense, but the decor did feel basic bordering on the austere. The Covent Garden branch, however, is perfect in every sense of the word. Mad Men is the description that most immediately springs to mind - it has a laid-back glamour from a previous age. One feels remiss for not turning up in a sharp suit, before relaxing with a whiskey and cigar. Or a proper man's cocktail. And boy does Hawksmoor do these well. I've been to far too many average cocktail bars where the principal is the sweeter the better. Hawksmoor's bar offers the best cocktails I've had in London so far. And I've had a lot of cocktails. The flavours are perfectly balanced, with the two rum-based drinks I ordered mixed perfectly and offering a bitter, almost herby-flavour drink; the kind you can imagine Hemmingway sipping. Of course, Hawksmoor is nothing without the food. We didn't have the steak, but if it's as good as the original branch, then it'll be one of the best steaks in London. The assorted lamb cutlets and ribs, though, were melt-in-the-mouth tender and delicious in every sense of the word. The lobster sandwich, though, was perfection between two slices of bread. I wouldn't often plump for lobster over a good cut of meat but this sandwich has won me over totally. Hawksmoor isn't cheap, but then you'd expect nothing else. But with food this good, and that rare thing of a restaurant bar I'd happily drink in without eating, with a stunning array of drinks, it's worth every penny. Eat, indulge and let your inner Don Draper out.

mHdR73zl1kkO-RFz6GxyHw.text: We came with friends and had a great meal. The ambiance is fantastic,  the wait staff was attentive and the food was very good. The best thing we had was the Yorkshire Rhubarb Tart. That was really fantastic. Overall, it was a nice evening out. The place is a bit pricey but otherwise very good.

BgxsWrJz8XPM9HsClqXIRA.text: Sunday brunch. Visiting from USA. Prime rib Yorkshire pudding. Bjg portions with generous serving of veggies. One of the best meals in London. Not overpriced for what you get. Gave us a few chocolates and wrote out welcome to the U.K. In caramel sauce. Nice touch!  Would come here regularly if we lived nearby. We have Lawrys in the USA but not the same level.

-6zzKh2YStPzghbjyyyBXQ.text: Wanted to try out steaks from different part of the world. Reservation for 4 on Wednesday evening. Ordered 800 grams porterhouse and bone-in prime rib to share. Sides of bone marrow, mac-n-cheese, cream spinach, both kinds of friends, heritage tomatoes and a salad. Ordered the meats medium rare but got rare instead  according to US standard. But the meat was tender so still very eatable. Ordered bottle of wine to celebrate a 6 year first date celebration of my son and his wife. Desert was the sticky toffee pudding and toffee sundae. Sticky toffee pudding a must try. All in all, it was a pleasant dinner meal with good company.

xUoZuNIsZtcT_Ur4JdWLvQ.text: The Sunday roast is one of the best meals I have ever had. Wonderful.

vn6gJsEztljD3TTmaXFtHA.text: Amazing​ steak dinner here!  We had a fabulous night out. The scallops were over the top beautiful in presentation and taste. We also enjoyed the traditional potted beef and bacon. Chateaubriand​ for 2 was delicious. All of the steaks including the ribeye and filet mignon were perfectly cooked. The sides of potato, mushrooms and asparagus were great accompanists​ to the main courses. My husband got the bone marrow side and loved it. Their custom cocktail called the Shaky Pete was so good. I never drink beer, but ordered one after trying my husbands. Our server, Felix, was outstanding! The loud, casual atmosphere was great for the kids too!!

6x08VUlmgeuI5XdGUx4hng.text: Super great steak in middle of London, also great local atmosphere. I took the prime rib steak medium rare, very tender.Also, they added 3 time cooked chips, which was the best chips I had for a while.1- cook in the oven2- fry on low temp3- fry in hot temp before serving

8sAQuWYHodeGRENOj7VZqA.text: My cousin recommended this steakhouse so   I was obliged to check it out while visiting her home city! Overall, it was quite good but had some misfires along the way.Most importantly, the steak was excellent.  I had the 300g filet mignon and it was cooked to perfection and complemented well with a side of creamy béarnaise sauce.  The thrice cooked chips were good but the classic English catsup was underwhelming, just too watery for my particular American tastes.  My wife is veggie and she usually fares well in San Francisco steakhouses because the sides are as compelling as the cuts of steak but it was not the case here.  The creamed spinach was sadly mediocre, like what you'd find at a family-style buffet restaurant or something heated up out of a can. The Mac n Cheese was a bit better, albeit with a little helping of salt and pepper.  Both our salads were disappointing, I'd pass on the traditional tomato salad and classic Caeser; they tasted like they were made by a someone following a recipe book for the first time and definitely absent of any locavore mindset.My cocktail selection was superb, I had the Manhattan for two (for one) and both the presentation and quality were wonderful.  The drink was served premixed in a chilled glass flask with old fashioned glasses, rock cubes, a slither of orange peel, and maraschino cherries on the side so you can pour your own from the staple elements.  I loved the experience and the flavor of the classic cocktail itself.Service was quite good, our server was polished and attentive in his approach.  My wife's second drink took a long time but otherwise, everything was on point. Overall, quite good but definitely some room for improvement around the edges.  And the edges do matter, it's what separates the good from the consistently great.

photos.caption: Photo of Hawksmoor Seven Dials - London, United Kingdom. Make Your Own Manahattan

U-oeteOPW-qUaV3tyQ_6qw.text: Been in London for two weeks, and this was my last feast before I leave to France.An excellent choice because it was hands down the best meal I've eaten in the United Kingdom. Completely changed the way I think of "British Fare".I started the meal with potted beef, bacon and Yorkshires and with the first taste I knew this was going to be a good experience. For my main course I had the aged rib-eye with stilton hollandaise and a side of macaroni and cheese. Everything was perfect. A++Cheers!

photos.caption: Photo of Hawksmoor Seven Dials - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Hawksmoor Seven Dials - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Hawksmoor Seven Dials - London, United Kingdom

350i_tiBUgbLweXrSBpQlg.text: I have now been here twice, and yes, it is one of the best meat restaurants in London. BUT both times I felt that the service was not that good, a little bit to detached or not caring. I ordered the Tamworth belly ribs as a starter and for main i've went for their fillet and mac & cheese as side. The food comes in quick, it taste good but the whole experience is not so nice. You dont really feel like you want to stay there longer, you are enjoying the environment or such. You just want to eat and leave. Thats why I will probably not give it a 5.

photos.caption: Photo of Hawksmoor Seven Dials - London, United Kingdom. Fillet with bearnaise and mac'n'cheese
Photo of Hawksmoor Seven Dials - London, United Kingdom. Belly ribs

DOMTDaID83vGTjt3igx7KQ.text: All considered,  I was quite satisfied with my experience here.  I chose it over the other available steak venues given it's average review here, walking distance to my hotel, and availability of seafood options as well.  Our table was ready within 10 minutes of our reservation time.  I also found the hostess and waitstaff attentive and professional.As for the menu, there were few seafood options but I was fine with this as I really had no intention of considering a non-steak meal at a steakhouse.  My wife and I both ordered the surf and turf.  This came with a 300 g filet.  I thought it was a great cut.  It was slightly overlooked, tending more toward medium than medium rare.  I also felt it was a tad over salted but on this issue my wife and I disagreed.  The sear, however, was excellent and the taste overall excellent.  It came with a half of lobster.  The lobster tail, what there was of it, was perfectly seasoned.  I would have preferred a whole lobster tail and have avoided the whole mess of extracting the meat from the claw.  That was a messy business but such is lobster.  I had a side of creamed spinach which wasn't particularly memorable but perfectly satisfying.  All in all, I have no major complaints and would try it again if the opportunity arose.

tOYO4pRqLFBw13rsMR5o7w.text: My husband eats meat (I'm veggie).Therefore I'm cool with kickin' it at steakhouses. In San Francisco, I can put together a full-on epic tasting menu from the sides' section of the menu.I expected no less from this well-rated steakhouse.Hold up. Slow down. Don't get excited. Not what happened.....I ordered the heritage tomato salad. The tomatoes didn't taste fresh, the onions and vinaigrette that accompanied it? Boring and bland.For my entree I ordered the macaroni and cheese and creamed spinach. The mac was decent after I baptized it in salt and pepper. The creamed spinach couldn't be fixed. The chips I shared with my husband were good, although the English ketchup was meh and too vinegary.The two wines I ordered, Malbec and Cabernet, were no good:( So, I settled for a vodka soda.  Two stars at best.I was left wishing din had been better...Until I had the STICKY TOFFEE PUDDING. Broke my taste buds.Wow! I'd only had something similar in Ireland.The pudding was in fact a sticky, buttery, toffee-dominated, fluffy yet creamy wonderful mess of a pudding. It was topped off with the smoothest tasting vanilla ice cream I've ever had. The night redeemed itself. I could've had ten of these! That dessert bumped this spot up to three stars!I'd go back for the dessert.

photos.caption: Photo of Hawksmoor Seven Dials - London, United Kingdom. Sticky toffee pudding

6Hu3mEAZkWLoKxDKfdYm-g.text: Great ending to our London trip! Had the herb chicken, scallops, filet, mac n' cheese and ended with the toffee pudding. The food was fantastic, service great and ambience wonderful.

c4EA57iZXp0yXgou0lVDRg.text: A good friend told me we had to have Sunday roast while in London so after some research I decided to make a reservation at the Hawksmoor. The first time I tried it was booked but then I tried again and was successful.The restaurant is near Covent Garden. We arrived early and browsed in the vendor stalls before making our way to the restaurant. We were a few minutes early but seated immediately.Our server, Ruben, provided exceptional service, making recommendations and answering all of our questions.We both had the Sunday roast meal with drinks. The roast was delicious and accompanied by lots of vegetables. Plenty of food. We also enjoyed our desserts. I had the sticky toffee sundae and it was a perfect way to end the meal along with a nice port.We sat near the bar so it was a bit loud but not too distracting.Definitely recommend for Sunday roast.

-wZcVjqjHsVPlQsf80-_vg.text: I gave Hawksmoor five stars about a month ago -- and my rating stands.  My family and I ordered all of Surf 'n Turf (fillet with half a lobster), fillet, and Sunday roast, and we all left feeling wow-ed.  I've always known Surf 'n Turf was good, but this second time experience was a testament to their consistency in performance.  Whilst it could be easy to get either the steak or the seafood wrong, Hawksmoor always gets both perfectly right, period.  My mum had the Sunday roast, and she loved it.  The meat was done just right, and all the sides harmonised perfectly with the meat as well.For sides, we ordered the spinach, mushrooms, and asparagus, all of which I highly recommend.  If you're looking to order fewer than three, I'd recommend the three in that sequence.Last but definitely not least, YOU MUST GO FOR THE STICKY TOFFEE PUDDING.  I had this with my colleagues by itself a couple weeks ago and since, have fallen in complete love with it.  Best dessert I've EVER had.  Top off your dinner with this heavenly dish, and you'll leave feeling happy for the rest of the week.

5ko98iNEoVIhRLbhRYpQVQ.text: From beginning to end, I can't say enough about our experience at Hawksmoor!  Husni was our waiter and was extremely attentive, knowledgeable about the menu and overall fun to talk to.  We came in after watching Mo Town and arrived a little before closing time.  We called to see if it was still ok to come in late and we were delightfully greeted by the hostess who was happy to have us regardless of the time!  Husni continued the good vibes with excellent service and recommendations that we certainly appreciated, especially because we were from out of town.  I had the porterhouse cut that was on special. Not sure how many grains but it was about 36 ounces.  We had creamed spinach as a side, potato and I believe a corn dish that was delicious.  For appetizer we did the Lobster and that was absolutely incredible as well!  All in all, great place, loved the ambiance and the food lived up to the expectations the staff set.  All in all, we loved our experience and we're thankful to Husni and the rest of the staff for the hospitality!

RxWC6tpXt3eh8j2MkkqlrA.text: I knew this place would be good. I hoped it would be very good. It turned out to be a short drive on past excellent and heading for perfection. Food, drinks, service, atmosphere - you name it, they smashed it.The journey to 5-star-ville began right from the charming front of house staff waiting behind the heavy wooden front door. They smiled respectfully rather than laughing in my face when I managed to forget that it was I who'd made the booking. Awkward silence over and bags safely stowed in their rather impressive giant wardrobe, we were led downstairs to the busy bar to wait for our 4th member.We pulled up 3 high chairs at the bar counter and the barman proceeded to make (the first part of) my night. Having perused the gorgeous cocktail menu for a while I was still stuck so asked for some advice of the whisky cocktail variety. The barman was sweet, he listened to what I liked, and he knew what he was talking about (the accent didn't hurt either). Though he then almost lost me by giving me a swig of their butter-infused bourbon to try - v generous but I could practically feel the clarified butter clogging my arteries. He didn't give up though, and after I made a much happier face at tasting a rye whiskey, he used it to make me a variation on a Manhattan (a Made Man). Full marks at the bar then :)Once our 4th member arrived there was a short delay before we were ushered through to the restaurant area, which had a lovely welcoming glow to it like someone had put a valencia filter on the room, and was humming with what sounded like happy eaters. We soon joined them - I shared a 750g chateaubriand with my steak buddy which worked out well as he could eat two-thirds and myself a third without wasting any. Nicely satisfying to see them cross it off the nearby chalkboard after we'd ordered it too - the larger cuts all depend on what they've got in stock. It was cooked to medium rare pink perfection, and with every delicious bite I finally understood all the people I'd heard raving about how the Hawksmoor guys know how to handle their meat. The other two had individual cuts which also looked beautiful, all teamed with some tasty sides (thumbs up for the triple cooked chips, though the creamed spinach is verry creamy) and a lush bottle of red. We somehow found room to share a couple of desserts afterwards too, with the sticky toffee pudding winning out over the choc and salted caramel tart.Service was smooth and attentive, and added a final touch of class to an all-round fabulous evening. The bill when it came was about £85 per head all in, including cocktails, wine and service, with our chateaubriand obv being the priciest item at around £95. So it's one for a special occasion/treat rather than an average dinner (sadly!), but I have to say, I've never more strongly felt that a meal in this price bracket was as worth it as this one. Probably biased by the fact that it had (almost) all my favourite things! Better start saving up a Hawksmoor fund for my next visit...

auTgFTPojxvBaEVbOGlyzg.text: Went here last October for a late lunch-dinner before flying out from London. The place was highly rated by other yelpers so I'd figure I give it a try. When entering the establishment you take stairs down and there's a big sign that reads 'Liberty and Beef' and I thought to myself, well nothing else could go wrong now :)I had the largest cut of ribeye, Yorkshire pudding and fries. the fries ( chips in the UK ) were amazing! Cool place, will def visit again.

photos.caption: Photo of Hawksmoor Seven Dials - London, United Kingdom. Hawksmoor had me as soon as I saw this sign... #suckerforsteak

XTJrLwNl2U2RHPr2fL3LDQ.text: This place is so good! The service was amazing. We were watching a show nearby, and needed a place to eat after the show. We thought that the restaurant closed at 2230, and my reservation was at 2230, so I thought that there was no way we were going to make it. We started looking for another place to eat, when the hostess called and said that the kitchen will wait for us! We were stoked! We walked in, and the place had a great vibe. The servers had recommended a number of things. I have had bone marrow all over the U.S. and have never had bone marrow as rich as they have them here. The steak was also nice and tender, and the peanut butter brittle for dessert is to die for.

photos.caption: Photo of Hawksmoor Seven Dials - London, United Kingdom. Bone marrow appetizer

2dgug7n8BRrvrRlMIhNB_A.text: I have been to Hawksmoor various times for steak and once at the Guildhall for breakfast, but I have never been for a Sunday lunch. I fixed that! As you would expect this is serious quality beef cooked with expertise. The roast dinner is huge so you are gonna have to come hungry or have stretchy trousers. The service seemed a little perfunctory, as in just doing my job. This wasn't the only time I have noticed this at Seven Dials Hawksmoor. All in all I would definitively recommend for steak or a Sunday lunch.

-izyTTC_xu0BQ4C37cC7LQ.text: If I have my birthday in London, this is where I go. It is not cheap, and it shouldn't be. The steaks are flawless, the bone marrow starter is... even thinking about it makes my mouth water, and the sticky toffee pudding is beyond belief. As if that weren't enough, the cocktail menu is incredible. I really recommend talking to the staff as to which drink goes well with your order, but do be aware that if you have one per course, for three courses, you won't leave in a straight line. The staff are super friendly, very knowledgable about their trade, and (here's the killer), will leave you alone while you're soaking in the warmly intimate, subterranean, atmosphere (and drooling slightly), but appear immediately from the glowing woodwork if you need them. The restaurant itself is beautiful, and not one detail has gone astray. I like their deft touch so much, I went looking for the -hand soap- they use in their bathrooms. I'd suggest a slightly later dinner on a week night, rather than an early one on a weekend, purely to fully appreciate the feel of the place. Finally, a brief honourable mention to my local branch in Spitalfields: Their Sunday roast is very very good, won't completely eviscerate your wallet, and is best enjoyed with a bottle of red between two to four. You will need to book ahead, and the atmosphere is a bit more bustling, but the food is no less amazing.

cpaJSBcFaV94gMlX6fBncw.text: Great steak and sides! I totally recommend the potted beef with Yorkshire pudding starter! Absolutely delicious! The staff are attentive without being over the top and they are always helpful. Great place for a good, hearty meal

Dx0Kx4hhfBurfBSdUwCfsA.text: Things did not get off to the best start here owing to mass confusion over how to get a table in the bar area. I arrived thinking my friends were there but when I attempted to go find them was firmly escorted and a warning hand was placed on my arm when they didn't materialise. Then discovered they were in a nearby pub having been told to come back in an hour. Table wasn't ready when we got back but suddenly appeared somehow  - because, as I later found out, my intimidating barrister friend had some stern words with a member of staff!Anyway this is all irrelevant because the Christmas Burger was the best burger I have ever had. It didn't even have beef in it. It featured buttermilk turkey, sausage patty, cranberry, cheese and god knows what else. It came served with roast potatoes and gravy. It was incredible. It says a lot for it that the other burger we tried, their classic version, was completely overshadowed even though it was probably the second best burger I've ever had. SO GOOD. And, at £15, incredibly reasonable for such great quality food (and a massive portion).

SYw3LM_mfK6I24Ezke2dLw.text: A divine slice of Covent Garden which will serve you well for a cocktail night or a romantic meal for two. I cannot get enough of the Hawksmoor brand (we have the menu but it's almost impossible!) and this branch is actually my new favourite.This menu here (thehawksmoor.com/wp-cont…) takes you through all of their unrivalled cocktail creations, with my personal fave being the Sinking Spritz.In terms of food, the mistake we always make it is order too many sides and get full before we finish.. my new approach next visit will be to have just a soup for lunch and arrive at the Hawksmoor ravenous :)

5FFt8y2-jdlFBHnXxMTQRw.text: Hidden in the corner of Langley Street, Hawksmoor Seven Dials is definitely a place for meat-lovers / carnivores. It lived up its reputation, by taste and price (not a budget experience, but worth it).We had 900g (you read that right) Bone-in Prime Rib, medium, to share between the 2 of us. It was perfectly cooked and seasoned (we avoid the sauces as it just tastes so good without them already) and each bite was a joy. For me, this may be too much meat in one go, but for a guy to share, this is as good as it gets. We had the mac and cheese on the side - one of my favourites, and we had purple sprouting broccoli, definitely needed some sides to counterbalance all the meat we were consuming.As full as I was already, there is always another stomach for desserts. I had the sticky toffee pudding and that was no disappointment. The pudding was like a warm lava cake, moist but not too dense, surrounded by sticky toffee (that got a bit too sweet at the end). It was a perfect match with the cold smooth vanilla (ice) cream. It was absolutely heavenly. If you're not impressed by the meat, you'd be impressed with this dessert. (On the side, lemon meringue pie was tangy, but had too much cream which was not the best option to end the night off).This place was almost perfect, though lost one star as I felt rushed by the waitress in the beginning to order my drinks, and the food off the menu. Mind you, she gave great suggestions, but I did not like the feeling of being rushed when I just got seated, while trying to take in the ambience/decor of the place and read the full menu before deciding what to order. Thankfully, no rushing vibe during the dinner itself when the food came.

8uS3diG_Qjktt2DRxLiMKw.text: My mother was in town for a birthday weekend and decided to give this place a try after all the good reviews. Needless to say this place definitely didn't disappoint. Started off with bone marrow and greens. Curiosity made me order it and it was absolutely amazing. Main was a 250g rib eye. I have tried a fair few steaks in my life and this had to be the best so far. Cooked to a perfect medium rare and perfectly seasoned. Along with the beef dripping chips it was simply heaven on a plate. It is making my mouth water just at the thought of it. To end was a sticky toffee pudding with clotted cream. I am not a dessert person but this was simply amazing. We were of to see a show and decided not the express menu. For £27 for three courses I wasn't expecting much for the money but we all left full so satisfied with everything. The service was perfect. Enough people to see to your needs but not be overbearing or leave you waiting for anything. Hands down I know I will be going here again and again and again.

3ivzTsyHtiqH3EscTEc4EA.text: Vegetarians beware - this is not the place for you.Was taken here for my birthday a couple of years ago and it did not disappoint, though I was uncomfortably full by the end of it. The Chateaubriand was excellent, but being less of a steak person I actually really loved the grilled bone marrow. Bookings recommended.

13cLiZy2oev461f5-_H_jw.text: If you're looking for steak in London, it doesn't get much better than the Hawksmoor. This beef is legit. You'll find all the major cuts on offer here, as well as an impressive list of special steaks meant to be shared among two or more people. I've now been to this particular Hawksmoor three times, and I've never been disappointed. I've had the Chateaubriand, Porterhouse, and fillet, and all of them have been amazing. The sides and desserts are equally delicious, so try some mac and cheese, triple cooked chips, creamed spinach, caesar salad, or really anything - you won't be disappointed and will most likely need to be rolled out of the restaurant! My favourite way to finish off the evening is with some sticky toffee pudding, and the Hawksmoor's is particularly amazing.One important note - I normally ask for my steaks to be cooked Medium-Rare, but here I go with Medium. I don't know why, but their ratings seem a bit skewed to me, so a Medium will come out with plenty of pink in the middle (almost rare even), so take that into account and make sure you talk to the server about how you want your steak cooked.

w_bhoRHyX4GaOisdu8kYCw.text: Hawksmoor is good and tasty and I especially enjoyed the Sunday Roast. It's great for groups and large parties. The space is nicely done and the service was good. They make a pretty good Spicy Bloody Mary which is always worth a star in my book. Everyone at my table enjoyed their feast and we even stuck around for some puddings which were nice. My friends booked this place and I'll certainly be back for another roast so see y'all there.

qqOJcJpt0kjQ6C8OldEKJA.text: Classy venue, convivial staff, convenient location and cracking food.Not a budget experience but worth it.Cocktails in the bar were great. Server was knowledgeable and fun without being too in your face. Starters were delicious, desserts fantastic but the main was amazing. We shared a large rib on the bone and the meat was tasty and perfectly cooked. Sides were also sensational - amazing chips, sauces, salads and veg. Slightly strange that your premium large steak comes pre-sliced in a skillet.  A bit disappointing that you don't get to fully appreciate your steak before its dissected for you!If you are near a Hawksmoor call in a give it a go. If you don't want the full on a la carte experience an "Express" fixed price menu is also available limited times.

kdKdEjQigX_YveDytyUGSw.text: Hands down one of my favorite places to eat.  Meat is out of this world and the side dishes are on another level (can never choose between them so always order way too many).  Great cocktails, deserts, service and atmosphere.  Will go back here again, and again. and again.

F2Z5D1m5oe2Ktk1tGMpCgg.text: Meat lovers....this is your home! Visited Hawksmoor after reading loads of positive reviews from fellow yelpers. I must say that it was well worth paying extra money for good quality meat. They offer various cuts of meat to suit your palate. The size is also variable based on how much you can consume. The server we had was very knowledgeable and attentive in giving us recommendation based on what we want. As for the ambiance, casual and classy but not snobby. If you enjoy the feel of British rustic decor, you will love Hawskmoor. In addition, I love the idea that this restaurant is located underground. It is literally below the buzzling streets of Covent Garden. Yes space is a problem in London but not so much here in Hawksmoor! Definitely spacious and airy here compared to the usual cramp and narrow British restaurants considering it is below the ground. Checkout.

ikem8o0DOtgPSpFADFN-GA.text: I had a really good experience with Hawksmoors. The food was excellent (especially the lobster), it had an extensive cocktail and wine list, and the servers were friendly, attentive and swift. Ambiance is dark and cozy and fitting a steakhouse. Not exactly cheap, but good value for what you get.

-t0iSbGRslnnk_iClCpyVA.text: Yummy!!!  Amazing food!  We have been to other Hawksmore's but the feel/look of this one is really our favorite.  It's high class food but you can come dressed up or casual.  The steaks are to die for!!

l5UtldrsyoI3rk55WfQiPw.text: I'm probably going to be hated for this review bit I've been to Hawksmoor 3 times now and each time found it worse and worse.I should probably clarify here that I don't eat red meat. But everyone I know does so I have had 3 dishes that are meant for non red meat eaters and they've ranged from dry and boring to bland and tasteless. Lobster? As I said before, grilled and therefore completely dry. Why not steam it so it retains it flavors and juices?Chicken? I did the Sunday Roast and since I don't eat red meat was given a half roast chicken instead. Yeah, it was alright. Plain and rubbery but alright.Fish? The menu said it was wrapped and cooked with chili and rosemary - but I'm quite sensitive to spice and I tasted nothing. Just plain flavourless fish. The plain chicken had more flavour, and everyone knows plain chicken doesn't have a lot of that. If you're a meat eater this place is great. If not, the best thing to do is come here and make a meal out of cocktails and sides. I recommend the carrots.

mmAiqrr2DhUEsylUZAItPw.text: Last night was my second time at the Hawksmoor for Sunday Roast... they did not disappoint. £19.50 for a Sunday Roast... not too bad in my books (more than your average pub Sunday Roast, but come on... you're at a steak house. You're going to get better food here so it's worth the extra £). Drinks are also fab, both cocktails and the non-alcoholic.  Staff are wonderful - our waiter was amazing and recommended his fav dessert (sticky toffee pudding with salted caramel ice cream), and OMG... this is the type of dessert that'll have you making bedroom noises and have the people at the next table looking over. Mildly embarrassing, but you won't care once you've tasted this. Make sure you make a reservation if you're going to visit!

-NIn6Si3JwLELI3VWs9GdA.text: Lovely place for lunch. Be warned you won't find light fare - it's a great spot for steak and wine. Service was great and very knowledgeable/

2DZBIyKeAT2arRvQvduagg.text: A little more than I'd pay on an average Sunday jaunt but hey, every morsel was gravy-drippingly worth it. My cousin and I chose the roast because really, what else were we going to choose? Apart from the intimidatingly large spinach leaves I polished everything off. The beef was as you'd expect from a restaurant prized for its meat - delicious. And a special shout out to the potatoes and Yorkshire pud. The welcome twist for me was a roasted half bulb of garlic which I smothered on everything (making a note to myself to pick up strong chewing gum on the way home).I also had a try of my sister's macaroni cheese. It's gone all trendy these days but was so glad to have the homely classic in front of me, done to perfection.

36bmXEixR09UA_5qoZPuvA.text: My man is a meat eater - and his idea of a perfect anniversary was steak.Since it was my turn to organise the festivities this year, I booked at Hawksmoor following the good reviews of my co-Yelpers here - and it did not disappoint.Hawksmoor is an underground (literally) hidden gem in the hart of Seven Dials. When entering you feel that you've just joined a secret club of steak eaters - you can tell it's a nice place, but it isn't overly posh or pompous. The menus are simple and straightforward: steak and stuff that goes with steak. Starters are mainly sea-food based, but we decided to go straight into business. We decided to go with a special cut of Porterhouse and share it between us, alongside a nice bottle of red wine and a few sides.And yes. Best. Steak. Ever. Okay, we did pay £72 for it (£9/100g - you chose your cut/size when ordering) - but totally worth it.The service was impeccable - friendly, helpful, and knew what they were talking about - but without that forced over-serviced attitude that I really hate.So yup - that's this place added to my "favourite places in London" list.

PqbGc5Acn2-jc2SsXO6CeA.text: Best atmosphere and staff in London.  We couldn't have loved the experience any more than we did.  Unbelievable good food, can't wait to go back!

sjGuV9ZLtxYFPopmf6f2gw.text: I love the casual vibe of this place, and the service is excellent.  However, in every regard Hawksmoor was underwhelming.  The steaks are, by American standards, not premium quality.  The meat is not dry aged, it's gristly/tough textured, and worst of all, it's not properly cooked (I asked for medium rare and received what may only be called -- generously -- "medium" (closer to well done!)).  The char the living hell out of the steaks and that's what you taste when you bite into them -- charcoal.  All that being said: the sticky toffee pudding is to-die-for.  But at the prices that they're charging for the rest of the meal (yikes!  the mediocre meat!), the dessert is not worth the trip.

abq1oKT-Rwq6_nIk49wXpw.text: Our final night in London & we were overdue for a decent meal. This place was recommend by one of our tour guides. We made reservations for 830 but arrived a bit late since it took us some time to find the place, although concerned they would give our reservations away once we arrived we had no problems being seated there was no need to rush as the restaurant was not crowded maybe they do give away reservations when the place is busy good for us this wasn't the case. Drinks we started with some House wine Red for me, Whiskey & soda for my friends drinks were good. Steak I had the Sirloin cooked medium rare along with a some Garlic butter & for a side I had the Mac & Cheese. Steak was amazing perfectly cooked juicy piece of meat the garlic butter was a great added touch simply because I love garlic butter. Mac & cheese was very good as well good taste, since I had my garlic butter did add some to the Mac , good call everything taste better with garlic butter. Friends had the Rib eye & another Sirloin both cooked well with Mash potato. Rib eye was very good nice taste. One of my friends had The Roasted chicken this was good the outside had a nice taste but a bit dry on the inside not too bad my friend had this with mash potato, good mash potatoes I added some of the garlic butter & yumm so good. There was little room left but one of us manage to try the Raspberry ice cream, wow ice was very tasty. As for the place itself nice restaurant pretty big with a bar area in the front when you first walk in, service was good & prices I say are expensive. Everything we had was delicious although it can be pricey it's really worth a try.

N98OQgMp0mLCwkQHBCCslQ.text: I had a lovely experience here. The bartender was just such perfection. We didn't have a reservation so we decided to sit at the bar while we waited the quoted 30min for our table. It actually took more than an hour but it didn't even matter because we had a blast tasting several drinks, some off the menu and some surprises that the bartender pulled together for us. Definitely an A++ on the drinks and hospitality on the bartender's part. He also recommended some spots to us for late night drinks. I wish I could remember the bartenders name!! The dinner was solid. It was fast service and we really enjoyed the scallop starter. The steaks weren't the best steaks we have ever had but still a solid Saturday night dinner. We will 100% be returning on our next trip.

F4XUJq5EVHtJGfae66CTyQ.text: I had five visitors from Japan and they wanted to go to steakhouse at the fancy place. I immediately imagine this place and reserved it on Thursday night. Only table available for six at the night was 9:30 PM! We reconsider to reserve other places but ended up to go for it. We started with scallops and some salads and ordered 1.3 kg of Porterhouse and a few grams of Ribeye and whole size of Lobster. Foods were all DELICIOUS and we had a great chat almost up till midnight.All the visitors loved the foods and especially the ambience of the restaurant and gratefully appreciated me for taking them to this restaurant and happily went back to Japan.

nkjvb8_TDrotuSLmf7AVuQ.text: Our first time in London, with the reputation of poorly prepared low quality food, I did not want to take a chance on our first dinner. We walked in without a reservation, the dining room was booked, but they offered us bar area seating. The ambiance was typical bar, lively and informal, the waiter was playful and very attentive. We ordered a 650 gram T-bone for me and a 300 gram Fillet. For sides we ordered butter greens, macaroni and cheese, and creamed spinach. Everything arrived at the same time, hot and well presented, for a Steakhouse. Which is to say, the sides arrived in their own small cast iron dishes and the steaks on a white plate. The steaks had a nice char to them and were cooked to a perfect medium rare. The first bite revealed a juicy morsel, well seasoned and that nutty-beefy flavor that only comes with dry-aging. The sides were all good, though the creamed spinach was a real standout. It was a great dinner and well worth the price. If you are in London and looking for a great steak, consider this a good bet.

o0Otb6-CIr85GxXXWPYH-A.text: As a native Texan, I am very particular about my steak.  The steak here was much better than I anticipated.  The restaurant is a bit claustrophobic as it in the basement.  We arrived early and had a drink at the bar, one of the few great classic cocktail bars we found in all of London. (Ask for Cara; she makes a great butter-infused bourbon old fashioned). In our quest to find the best sticky toffee pudding in London, this was one of the best, albeit only slightly better than Rules.  Unlike other reviews, I was not overly impressed with the bone marrow, but it is definitely worth the try.  I enjoyed the heirloom tomato on toast much more.  Side note: if you are old like me, you may remember the McDonalds fries from early 70's when they were cooked in beef suet. The fries here are cooked the same way.  It was nice revisiting my childhood.  The funniest part of the evening was that the homemade ketchup of which they showed great pride and is for the fries, not the steak, was so cold it would not come out of the bottle.

AWG9oN7M9vENvC5kQ4Q0Fw.text: [+]- Great ambience, modern American looking steakhouse.- Excellent cocktails, go for them if you drink.- Reasonable priced menu with generous portion size.- Delicious food.[-]- Slow service.

sjsakZFifpCU-V-onSwHlg.text: One of my favourite restaurants in London！The place was fantastic. And it looked so British that I felt like I was having dinner in a movie. The experience was great，and the staff there was really nice！
