EUoRwZi6Ao4Je7fDzBPBgQ.text: Screw my new anti red meat/mostly fruit and veggie diet, I'm off to the Hawksmoor! My stomach is grumbling in a fit of pleasure and pain (nudge nudge, wink wink). This place made me devour excessively and I loved every minute of it. It's such a friendly place, a well designed restaurant with the emphasis on the quality of the food and the satisfaction of the customer. There is little or no formality; you're served by wonderfully casual hippie servers who know their stuff, passionate about food and genuinely happy to help.If you like gin and especially gin cocktails this is your place, so so so many on the list and the one I had was wonderfully sublime and refreshing on a hot day. They also had a huge selection of whiskeys, with everything from a 15 year old Springbank, to to several Japanese whiskeys to a great peaty Monkey Shoulder. I was of course utterly charming and the barmaid let us taste all of them! (hic)The food nearly made me cry in pleasure; heaven!Boneless spare ribs with a fennel, cumin, chilli and maple syrup sauce.A sublimely tender and rare 55 day aged T-Rump, chips fried three times, (three times just to make totally sure at least one thing here is fully cooked!)This left no room for dessert  but all topped with a good cabernet sauvignon (Hawk Crest 2006, Napa) I need to try more scrummy things that will also destroy my anti red meat diet like the bone marrow or the kimchi burgers. nom nom nom

JaAYcCQwgf6OstIehrFSjQ.text: Lovely atmosphere in a great location - make sure you book as it's always busy especially on a Sunday for their roast! Definitely worth going for a Sunday roast the beef is gorgeous. However there roast potatoes and veg really let them down. On the plus there cocktails and desserts are delish. Would go back as it is a nice place to go with friends for a slightly 'posher' feel roast, buuut bare in mind it is a bit pricey.

f2HkJBGOGMEKVBXMhk15ag.text: Woah. I actually GIGGLED when I took my first bite of the juicy, tender fillet steak. Unintrusive, unpretentious, service for such a pricey establishment. The combination of atmosphere, quality of food, and service do well to justify the cost. I get it now.

QPs7oyrnP7LiG7jcbmvfpw.text: In my search for a great steakhouse for a dinner to celebrate my husband's birthday I struck gold with this place. First of all its in a splendid neighborhood of Seven Dials. I really dug the layout of the joint with low lighting and a separate bar area. The menu was superb, I went with the surf & turf with the Stilton dressing for the filet. My lobster & filet was perfectly cooked. My side of choice was the macaroni & cheese. My husband went with the 1kg bone in prime rib which was sheer massively delicious. Highly recommend this place if your looking for a big meal night out. Reservations are needed for dinner. Smart casual on dress. Decent cocktails for the slow sippers.

GTv-8hJM_orvS4IjuL9qGw.text: Excellent service. Go with the scallops and half lobster to start. The meat is a bit over cooked so always order it cooked less that you prefer. Free range chicken surprisingly delicious for a meat place.

FbQ3eMENDrvQ8Yg3IsszzA.text: Our last night in London, this place had a nice atmosphere, good but not amazing food, but the sticky toffee pudding for dessert was amazing and the cocktails were excellent as well.

Erhr4u1lYzOHhXi3l39E2Q.text: Although I am not a massive steak fan I was dragged along to Hawksmoor by a friend promising it was the best steak she'd ever eaten. Safe to say I was sceptical but soon my worries were gone as I can safely say this was hands down the best steak I have ever had. The wait for food was a little longer than average but as we had cocktails to sip on we didn't really notice. The staff were friendly and checked on us every so often to make sure things were ok, as well as taking time to explain all the different steaks. The fries complimented the steak well and as a whole was a wonderful meal. It was very busy but I think it just gave a nice atmosphere which was nice. I had the rib-eye steak which I definitely recommend - was full of flavour and cooked perfectly. I would recommend (and have done) this restaurant to anyone.

omc-PDcosbpNkEWJYjGqMA.text: Enjoyed the Sunday roast at Hawksmoor last weekend. The meal came with a large piece of steak, carrots, greens, potatoes, Yorkshire pudding, shallots, garlic and a bit of gravy to pour over top. Service was great and the ambiance was lovely.

r8rQBeALGnR3QwnCZU3mAA.text: Hawksmoor - best steak in LondonFood (steaks):I've tried a variety of cuts namely Bone-in Prime Rib, Porterhouse, and the Rib-eye. Obviously each is slightly different but each is phenomenal for what it's meant to be.Generally awesome marbling and perfect seasoning meaning that each bite is a joy. I prefer to avoid the sauces (because you really don't need them) and just go with a dash of mustard.Food (burgers):I've only had the hawksmoor burger once, and I was hungover so standards might have been lower. That being said, it was a little piece of heaven. Juicy (so so juicy), flavorful, moist, tender, the right size, bun came toasted and didn't completely dissolve as you ate the burger. For 15 pounds, it can't be beat. (Nb. Hawksmoor burger only available at Seven Dials and Guildhall)Sides:Solid but underwhelming. If only Hawksmoor and Goodman could merge (Hawkman!) and serve steaks from the former and sides from the latter, true perfection would have been achieved. That being said, they're decent and great value. Bone marrow is an absolute steal at 4 pounds, the triple cooked chips are decent, likewise for creamed spinach and Mac and cheese.Desserts:I'm usually too full, but special mention for the cornflake ice cream (also available as a milkshake). Invented at momofuku and now a fairly global trend, this whole idea of cereal flavoured desserts is definitely a winning combination.Note: I had an average experience at Spitafields once where everything was criminally under seasoned. Probably best to stick to Seven Dials to be safe.

photos.caption: Photo of Hawksmoor Seven Dials - London, United Kingdom. Steak, Fried eggs, Bone marrow, and a Cornflake milkshake. So good.

rDL1PWThmsxV5cocJgFCMg.text: H oly crap!! Best dinner I had whilst in London!A wesome service, from beginning to endW e ordered everything our server suggested :]K icked it off with pork belly ribs app [OMG GET IT]S irloin was cooked perfectly, medium-rare-rareM arrow as side is better deal than as app~O utstanding Malbec blend, Hawksmoor exclusiveO rgasmic sticky toffee pudding to top it off, yummoR ustic & classy place, perfect for date night!

ZtGthzT7NKar4qlWtHxhMg.text: Absolutely delicious! My cousin recommended this place as the best roast dinner in London. It absolutely didn't disappoint! I had the roast chicken and my husband had the beef and we both loved it. We got three different desserts to put in the middle of the table that we all shared. Three of us had wine and my husband had the full day buttered old fashioned which he said was delicious. The staff were lovely. We had a wonderful time.

H6Ign0miub1Cjdu9srMUDA.text: Great steak, and sides, dessert was incredible. Would go back for the steak and sticky toffee pudding any day. Great service as well. I was tempted to buy the cookbook but did not. Meat was prepared fantastically with great flavor. They write up on the chalkboards what cuts are still avail in the kitchen.Skip the burger and go with steaks, burger was just okay. Really wanted Sunday Roast but it wasn't avail.

WKfyC6eEC1C4d0lJyt8Zug.text: Our first official Sunday roast after living here almost two years and we had a great first experience! We had been wanting to try one of the Hawksmoor restaurants for some time now so what better way than Sunday roast!? It is totally a bargain for 19.50 too!We opted for the Roast rump of Longhorn beef which is only served Sundays and comes with veggies and fried potatoes. The meat was cooked and seasoned well but could have been a bit juicier. The fried potatoes were so silky inside! YUM! We also tried the creamed spinach which was cold and blech. The macaroni was quite good though.

HPxAXrSzsV6gc9437CwXFg.text: For a £20 roast dinner you can't complain about the monstrous slab of well seasoned meat accompanied by the sweetest of carrots, a behemoth Yorkshire pud and sublime roasty tatties. The only let down was the slightly blunt, vulturous waiter.

E9xm0dsJu2PkwZhZ50QqPw.text: This meal will go down as one of the best I've eaten in my life. Everything about the experience of eating at Hawksmoor Seven Dials was superlative. The ambience was exactly what I imagined it would be like to eat at a restaurant in London: loud, mysterious, underground, dimly lit, and comfortable to the extreme. The ribeye steak I ordered was the best beef I've ever had (by a long shot) and it was cooked to perfection.  I found myself a favorite drink in Shaky Pete's Ginger Brew, which was equivalent to tasting something straight out of a Harry Potter book. The salad, apps, and sides were too good to even believe it was real life. The waiter had the most above-and-beyond sense of hospitality and more charisma than I thought was humanly possible. (Definitely not something you'd find in the US) To top it all off, the Sticky Toffee Pudding was easily in the Top 5 things I've ever tasted in 30 years of existence. Most importantly was that this place offered one of the most unique "last night of vacation" dinners I've ever been fotunate enough to share with my family. We are a very picky bunch, and pleasing everyone in our party is a rare occasion. More than just making everyone happy, this place knocked our socks off with the tastes that hit our table.  I can't wait to visit London again to find myself back at one of the Hawksmoors. This is an imperative stop  if you're visiting The Old Smoke.

V9HcSvoDx-h3Z7KsQLUdTA.text: We did had a reservation and we were in aww once we went downstairs. The table was Pete t. The service a bit slow... nothing major but the food - YUM we tried the beef potted something, never had it but very impressed with it. The steak, WELL - it was perfect. The size was just right for two and the wine to go with it was Devine. The stag was very friendly and oops I regret not taking pics! I would recommend this place over and over again.

-DZRtVC-r9VAJGnmrIEqNQ.text: The Hawksmoor is a classy London establishment known for having some of the best beef around. It is no surprise their burger features premium beef with bits of bone marrow worked in. The burger is topped with Guebben chese, pickle, lettuce, red onion, a house sauce, and served with a side of housemade ketchup. All of this is packed onto a tender brioche bun. I ordered my burger medium and it was cooked to perfection with a nice char. The beef was juicy and had a lot of flavor. However, it's a shame that this great piece of beef is paired with some confused ingredients. The Guebben cheese is rather powerful and combines with the house made ketchup that is very tangy/sour as well. I only added the house made ketchup to the burger after my first few bites; since I found the burger was lacking some salt/acid to really make your mouth water. Overall, this is a solid burger if you do not put the awful house made ketchup on top. The bun is great, the beef is great, the other condiments work well...it is just one sauce or cheese substitution away from being a fantastic burger.

photos.caption: Photo of Hawksmoor Seven Dials - London, United Kingdom. Hawksmoor Burger

CsRshDNo8ky6q-TIKXaOqg.text: Safe bet!Awesome Chateaubriand, to die for beef dripping potatos, plus attentive service and a great wine selection...Carnivors: Go there!!!

photos.caption: Photo of Hawksmoor Seven Dials - London, United Kingdom. Steak heaven!

K8-dErXUGw06s_E7GhTFew.text: Starters were beet salad that offered some surprise to the palate and the mushroom and spelt was excellent and had us looking forward to the main course! We had the porterhouse (900g @ £9.25/100g) split among2 adults and 2 children. Portion was just right. Steak was cooked nicely to medium, tender not chewy, perfect texture. Sides we have mac cheese which was crispy on top and creamy on the inside without going overboard. Mash in gravy was good too, smooth and tasted like spuds not powdered. The pre cocktail hawksmoor Collins was good as well, tangy with a tinge of bitterness yet easy to drink.

photos.caption: Photo of Hawksmoor Seven Dials - London, United Kingdom. Porterhouse
Photo of Hawksmoor Seven Dials - London, United Kingdom. Mash in gravy
Photo of Hawksmoor Seven Dials - London, United Kingdom. Mac cheese

8LtURiWCxhimloReYqgRGw.text: Goodman's better on every level. So i have to take my rating down.

2vFcFVKGyvzRKy8ve144yg.text: Heaven on a plate for the true carnivore you know you are...We were staying at the Trafalgar Hotel on a business trip, and some internet sleuthing turned up this place.  We were looking for a really British experience, Yanks that we are, but we were nervous about trusting our dinner to Yelp, and so consulted with our hotel concierge. No, No, he said...I know a place that is better! So we followed his advice and wound up at - An American steakhouse in the touristy part of the West End - just what we did NOT want! So, we pulled out our trusty Google Maps app and navigated our way over to the Hawksmoor. And it was soooo worth the trip.It was very crowded when we arrived at about 9PM, but they were able to seat us right away in the bar area, which was fine with us. We debated over the wine list, as we were unfamiliar with the choices in our price range. Seeing our dilemma, our helpful waiter sent over their sommelier, who steered us to a bottle that he felt would suit us. Our mission for the night - aside from satisfying our primal desire to gorge on a really fine hunk of meat - was to try things that we were, as Americans, unfamiliar with.  So here is a summary of what I had... (I'd tell you what the rest of my group had, but after two bottles of wine and a dessert Scotch I find I don't really remember!)Starters - Potted Beef with bacon and Yorkshires - 8.50Where do I begin? Perhaps I should compose a Broadway love song in honor of this dish, it was so incredibly good. The rich gravy, the delicious Yorkshire...all incredibly melt in your mouth and savory...I could have been happy with this dish alone for the night. Steak - the Ribeye, done medium rare - 30.00If you are a steak lover, well...you came to the right place. Hawksmoor knows steak, and serves only the best. This was probably one of the best steaks I have ever had, cooked to perfection.  The portion was more than enough for one person.Sides - I know we all shared the following:Triple cooked chipsElliot's Bread and ButterRoast field mushroomsThey were all good, but didn't stand out in my memory - they were just happy side dishes that complemented the food.Dessert - I opted for a closing glass of Scotch rather than a sweet, and can tell you wholeheartedly that you cannot go wrong with the Highland Park 12 year old. Enough said.So, food aside - about the Hawksmoor itself. We arrived from the cold outdoors into a waiting room that was cozy and warm. The folks greeting us at the door were very friendly, even though the place was clearly incredibly busy. We fully expected to be turned away, as we had not made a reservation, but they offered to seat us in the bar area, and we jumped at the chance. The wait staff in the bar area were incredibly friendly and attentive, taking lots of time to sit with us and explain the options for wine, food, and anything else we cared to ask about. And this is one note - while I enjoyed the friendly banter and very friendly approach of the waiters, other people in my party would have preferred a more formal approach. So, if you would prefer white glove, more aloof interactions, this is not the place for you.The place itself has lots of ambience and atmosphere, and doesn't feel touristy at all. Next time I am in London, I will visit the Hawksmoor again!

bUkRyLdgWWl9EAW9UwhKJQ.text: We ate at Hawksmoor during their their "soft opening" and a couple of times since--we have never been disappointed. In fact, we've never had anything less than a superlative experience there. We like the Covent Garden location because it's easy to reach from the tube station and is of course very central. The hamburgers are lovely, but the bone marrow starter and their chips are really fantastic. I especially love the porterhouse, medium rare, which I sometimes share with other people.

5ItvP_MW9NoAVTeF2sAaFg.text: Hawksmoor is consistently solid. I normally visit the Hawksmoor in Knightsbridge but gave Seven Dials a shot as Knightsbridge was fully booked.Unsurprisingly, the experience was pretty much exactly the same as other Hawksmoor locations. Always dark and broody, generally swift service and friendly wait staff. The steaks are solid without being amazing and there's a variety of sides ranging from super healthy to decadent.The wines by the glass list at Seven Dials could've been deeper - I think there was about 6 to choose from? From memory other locations have a longer list including some NZ reds.In short, if the price was about 25%~30% cheaper it might come in at 5 stars. You can get equal or better steaks in Australian restaurants for about 50% of the price but hey - this is London after all!

9wNa9qjkdwtnCE9uGmlEDA.text: A standout meal in London. Not only was the staff SUPER accommodating to our lateness due to the Underground shutting down, but they were friendly, informative about the dishes and prompt. We had steak and fish. Both expertly prepared. Best gin martini of the week in London. We will be coming back.

zJkqzrhOJI19NH4jf7qgfQ.text: Wow, I went to the Hawksmoor for breakfast around christmas time and the food was just fantastic. If you would like a treat and a little cure for a hangover head to the hawksmoor in the city and they will fix you. It costs about £34 for the breakfast and there is too much food for two people on it. The food is grilled on a charcoal grill and tastes delightful. They serve cocktails named "anti fogmatics" to clear away your fog, these include a fantastic Bloody Mary.I would definitely recommend the Hawksmoor

HufNwwgjCNYU9TMbxPVFbg.text: Everything was great! The food was tasty and the bone marrow was wonderful. But I think that the prime cuts if meat are grossly overpriced. Go for the special which won't dissapoint.

5m-G1hqbKf0muTqQUHPzMw.text: Without a doubt the Hawksmoor is one of London's great steakhouses. 5 huge stars. It is my go to place for meat. Their Sunday roast is one of the best meals you can possibly have. Perfectly executed roast of beef accompanied by triple cooked chips, glazed veggies, decadent gravy and of course a Yorkshire pudding. The only down-side is that the Hawksmoor also serves one of the best burgers in London...a decadent patty with nuggets of bone marrow and has arguably London's best assortment of steaks (bone in rib eye!) on the menu. Ah, the dilema of too many choices!The Hawksmoor serves delicious cocktails...while it's renown (and rightfully so) for its amazing collection juleps...the real winner on the beverage menu is the Bottle Manhattan for 2 or 4 (note nothing is stopping you for having the Manhattan for 4 when there are just 2 of you). It's a make yourself Manhattan served with all the accompaniments you would expect.The Seven Dials Location is a massive underground space with plenty of large tables  (perfect for a big group).Going to the Hawksmoor for roast is an absolute must!

photos.caption: Photo of Hawksmoor Seven Dials - London, United Kingdom. Sunday roast!

W7HS5sODhh2wOBs-5AKQyg.text: Amazing dinner!  Best steaks in London.   Fantastic atmosphere as well.

U8uUDpZO9r2okZOHYvr-cQ.text: My favorite bar in the covent garden! The cocktails are fantastic and food is really good as well. The roast is top notch - would recommend that. Ambiance is perfect too - if I had to be in a downstairs bar / restaurant, hawksmoor is the place I'd want to be!

Q3ICj_TQUIJzpbRWxPnULA.text: Went here for the review of the StickyToffee Pudding and came away with the best Fish and Chips (the fish predominately) I've eaten in the UK. The fish is brought daily from Mitch Tonks in Dartmouth, whose restaurant Rockfish there I had just enjoyed days before not knowing any relationship prior to the Hawksmoor server telling me. She was great by the way! The home made ketchup for the chips was spectacular as well but I took a star away for the chips. Good but plain and didn't seem hand cut. The Sticky Toffee Pudding was the best I've ever had though I must say I'd prefer a scoop of great vanilla ice cream on top instead of the clotted cream. I'm sure you can ask for that. Excellent pricing on the 3 course lunch menu and you can easily split one menu between two people.

PqRYqOgkbyaYl0LKW9kZug.text: Great venue hidden on the streets of seven dials, dark exterior, lively buzzing atmosphere inside. Booked a table very last minute online and was so glad we got a chance to go and visit. Checked into the bar first where me and a friend ordered the champagne Charlie's. Very, refreshing glass of gin lemon moet champagne concoction. Goes very well with any type of dishes from their menu. I opted for the grilled chicken and was surprised to how large the plate was. For a very small person like myself, found it extremely difficult to finish and also the chicken itself was very dry!!!! Needed a sauce or gravy, not something I'd order again. The triple cooked chips were ok, but the English herb salad was light and refreshing. The service was good and was happy. I'd revisit again, and definitely choose something different, maybe a lighter option so I leave space for dessert. Great concept inside, love the bar area, very welcoming and staff are very friendly.Very pleased and happy to return again :)

photos.caption: Photo of Hawksmoor Seven Dials - London, United Kingdom. Champagne charlie

tXwlOLEllRrR1-UfSgGbMQ.text: What Can I Say about SUNDAY ROAST other than   prepare to leave in a  FOOD COMA yes it is that good ...

-lJUU8iz2aP4Dvewp8W6Rw.text: My mom and I went here before a show at the Cambridge Theater last week. We arrived around 4:30 pm (we wanted to beat the dinner rush since we didn't have a reservation). The regular dining room doesn't open until 5:00 pm, so we sat in a booth in the bar and it was great - it didn't effect the service or experience at all. Leo was our server, and he was amazing! If we went back we would ask for him specifically. He made the whole dining experience so fun and enjoyable. We ordered everything he suggested, even if it was something we wouldn't have normally ordered. And, all of his recommendations were SPOT-ON. The shining star of the dinner was the Ribeye steak with Stilton Hollandaise sauce. This was absolutely the best steak I've ever had in my life. (Better than OXO Tower.) I've been to London 4 times now and this was by far the best dining experience I've had while traveling here. My only regret is that I was too full to get desert. I can only imagine how delicious it would have been!

photos.caption: Photo of Hawksmoor Seven Dials - London, United Kingdom. Creamed spinach, macaroni and cheese, maple bacon, Stilton hollandaise sauce, chips, and ribeye steak.

AOYfiInVHJEeeT-5kYz8nw.text: Recommended by a coworker, this was my first meal in London and by far the most memorable. We came around 5:30 for the Express Menu - 23 GBP for 2 dishes or 26 for 3. Started off with the Caesar Salad, which was nice and different 'cause it was the whole leaf. But WHY didn't I order the Bone Marrow which was simply mind blowing. Luckily our friend let us try a bite. It was my first time eating bone marrow and it was DELICIOUS. The caramelized onions on top paired with the mushy bone marrow - perfect combination that reminds me of French onion soup. Even better eaten on top of the crispy toast, which is slightly burnt and buttery. The presentation was also nice - a large portion sliced lengthwise instead of in chunks which imo looks much less appetizing. For the main, we all got the rib eye. Sauces are extra so my plate was literally just a piece of meat. It was very tender. For the side, I got the chips - thick cut, crispy outside, fluffy inside and slightly salty - Yum! But even better was the Beef Dripping Potatoes , which is potato chunks, crispy outside, fluffy inside. The ketchup also tastes good with a slight Worchershire sauce flavor. I was too full for dessert but I did try a bite of the Sticky Toffee Pudding which was heavenly! Also my first time trying; I had always imagined it to be super sweet and caramel-y, but the texture was more like a warm lava cake, moist but not too dense, with just the right amount of toffee/caramel flavor.The bone marrow and sticky toffee pudding were so good that we had to return for lunch a few days after to eat it again (and that's saying a lot, with the limited time in London and the abundance of good food choices!)This time, we tried the Burger (cooked medium rare, with blue cheese. very big portion) and the Whole Sea Bream - very nicely cooked. The sides were Buttered Greens (yum! Sprout Tops -more of a thicker leaf), baked sweet potato, and beef dripping potatoes again. Highly recommend this restaurant!

ArUjHL0Mh93boOt2P1bTxg.text: Nothing but love for the meal  and experience we had tonight.  From the moment we walked in (great hostesses) to the amazing bartender and drinks at the bar - we - had a feeling we'd stumbled onto something special.  Then we sat down and was served by Mark from Estonia who made the entire evening even more special than the food itself.  Yay for awesome service!Great service, great food (filet + mac & cheese) and dessert made us leave talking about what a great night it was all around.  Bottle of wine and dessert + a reasonable bill made tonight A+.Thanks Hawksmoor for the best meal of the week so far in London (from California).  We will be back in the future -- no doubt about it!

bINj8xhLr8o0bnU8WjmgTg.text: Superb service, food, atmosphere, decor. Just perfect.The cornflake milkshake is a must try as was the five pork chef special burger we had in the bar, that came with pork scratchings and some of the greatest triple cooked fries I've ever had the pleasure to taste. For £15 for the burger special, its quite reasonably for Covent Garden and you'll have a blast in the bar.Next trip, will probably want to visit this place for weekend brunch which I've heard is quite special too!

photos.caption: Photo of Hawksmoor Seven Dials - London, United Kingdom. Corkflakes Milkshake
Photo of Hawksmoor Seven Dials - London, United Kingdom. Triple Cooked Chips
Photo of Hawksmoor Seven Dials - London, United Kingdom. Five Pork Burger Close up

44Z7d6BoIPSco6-5P8YViQ.text: THE BEST STEAK I EVER DID HAVE!That should say it all really, but on top of that there was succulent lobster, and amazing cocktails, and helpful staff, and great wine and brilliant starters....As a long time Gaucho lover, and a steak aficionado, I'm whole-heartedly a convert to Hawksmoor and this place is probably now my favourite restaurant in the UK - now if only they had one where I actually lived!

photos.caption: Photo of Hawksmoor Seven Dials - London, United Kingdom. Beef above liberty!

5OIR2_I07sWLHRbnikpTdg.text: I've been here a twice and each time it's been delicious. As a student here in London...I don't have lot's of funds therefore I try and look for some great deals. The first time I went, my friend went online and found this place and it had some great reviews. After looking at their extensive menu we both decided to try the D-rump steak...it's only £20 which is a steal. We weren't quite sure what exactly D-rump is but we decided to try it anyway because other reviews stated that it was really good and even tender although it's a rump steak. Anyway we ordered the steaks medium rare and got a side of Beef dripping fries for £4.50 and the mac and cheese for £5. I have to say both were DELICIOUS! :) They also have an assortment of different mustards if thats what you like to eat with your steak....and YES I DO!!!!As for the second time I went to Hawksmoor Seven Dials...I basically ordered the same exact thing...and yes...I plan on going again but I want to try the pay by the weight steaks... :) YAHOOO~!

YCf3uOlEFoqDSQWAOlnzOA.text: Really good steak, but expensive. Costed me 50-60quids. But if you are looking for some quality beef this is the right place to go to!Update: tried the Sunday roast, delicious!!! Very large portion, alot cheaper as well (20quids)

JfSX7-0upI10sLDxZwWFbw.text: I had lunch there on a Monday. People started coming after 12:40, so it doesn't seem to be hard to get a table if you get there early, on Mondays anyway. Service was really good, polite and patient. My fillet with roasted wild mushrooms on the side was amazing and the wine they suggested me was exactly what I wanted. For dessert I got 2 scoops if lemon curd ice cream. It'll be difficult to loose all those delicious calories.

photos.caption: Photo of Hawksmoor Seven Dials - London, United Kingdom. 2 scoops of lemon curd ice cream to finish a great lunch.
Photo of Hawksmoor Seven Dials - London, United Kingdom. Fillet, medium. Roasted wild mushrooms on the side. Perfect match.

dnc9fiRxAdnR1O5-T1pyDA.text: I love Sunday roasts and was really excited to try the Hawksmoor's version, which my flatmate had been raving about. It was was quite tasty and a pretty good deal, at £19.50 for a huge plate of food. I am a total red meat junkie and I thought the meat was just okay. It wasn't the most fabulous, but it was good enough for the price and amount of food. The service was lovely and the food came out extremely quickly, which was a plus!

photos.caption: Photo of Hawksmoor Seven Dials - London, United Kingdom. Sunday Roast!

n2GLyNUMNo5okM6uXA_ErA.text: My friends and I chose Hawksmoor Seven Dials as our Thanksgiving dinner location away from home and we did not regret our decision. I ordered a salad, a steak (fillet)  mash with a cider on the side. My meal was out of this world, and our service was excellent. Would definitely pay Hawksmoor another visit if I'm ever in London again.

P5ITY_thGbKPfwIuUmaJyw.text: Hawksmoor is a fabulous place to have a meal. The restaurant has a chilled ambiance and tasty food. I enjoyed half a lobster, chateaubriand, creamed spinach, mac and cheese and triple cooked chips. I have had slightly better steak and mac and cheese at another popular steak restaurant but overall experience has probably been better here. Great waitress and sommelier who topped off our evening.

kJAg6hqSzKLSnGMalXgN3Q.text: Ordered the Rib Eye, Creamed Spinach, Pot Pie, Bone Marrow, Lobster and the Toffee Bread Pudding. Yes we went above on the ordering lol. Staff is very friendly and there is a sommelier. Your typical steak house but everything taste amazing!!!!

Gr_AKMcWvyz31E4wtCkiaA.text: Hawksmoor has a good and tasty offering for London standards. Did I have the best steak and sides of my life? No, not even close but it's hard to compete with Dallas steakhouses.First, the restaurant itself is located in a basement and is very large - much larger than I expected. Due to the fact that it is in a basement, there are large columns/poles throughout the restaurant which make traversing the dining room and getting in/out of your table somewhat tricky, especially after a few martinis.Second, the dress code (we visited on a Sunday night) was a bit of everything. There were some who were very dressed up and others who were very casual. My husband and I fit in somewhere in the middle. I donned dark jeans and a dressy top and he also wore dark jeans with a button-down/dress shirt.My husband and I both ordered the bone-in sirloin - both cooked medium. Our two steaks arrived and they were cooked and salted differently. What surprised me is how thin the steaks were. I should have been expecting this but given the Hawsmoor reviews and the fact that it's a bit more upscale, I thought I would be delivered an inch-thick steak as I would be at any steakhouse in Dallas/Fort Worth. So, it was a bit disappointing to see this skinny steak appear in front of me. My steak was pink in the middle but was a bit too overdone for me. Technically, it would fall within the "medium" range but more toward the "well-done" end of the spectrum versus the "rare" end. My husband's steak was opposite, it was cooked medium but more toward the rare end. My steak did not taste that great and his tasted a lot better, so being the southern gentlemen that he is, he switched steaks with me and used a bit of the sauce whilst eating my steak (which is totally sacrilegious, by the way!).For our sides we ordered:1) Macaroni [&] cheese - it was good, our favorite of the sides.2) Mash and gravy - it was OK. Gravy should never be served with mashed potatoes when served with steak. I did not care for the gravy but since it was served already poured over the mashed potatoes, I had no choice but to eat it. I recommend asking for the gravy on the side.3) Creamed spinach - just a warning, this is not the same type of creamed spinach you would get in the States. It was basically muddled spinach with a tiny bit of cream. It somewhat tasted like wilted spinach with no seasoning that had been boiled in water. My husband was terribly disappointed as creamed spinach is one of his favorites.Was the steak at Hawsmoor the best steak I have consumed at a restaurant in London? Yes but to be honest, the steaks we purchase from the butcher (with a thickness of "two fingers") and grill at home are far superior, mainly because of the thickness. When steaks are too thin, it is difficult to obtain the salty crust because one must grill them longer and by doing so, runs the risk of overcooking the steak. Would I return to Hawskmoor? Yes but I'd order my steak medium rare, skip the creamed spinach, order the mashed potatoes without gravy and of course, order the mac and cheese.

8Mhbad0Kw-8w_EJ6Q8V7nA.text: One of the highlights of our London visit - go figure. Amazing food and service. We had the french dip and the steak sandwich along with two kinds of fries.  The cereal milkshake rocked as did the sticky toffee dessert. Really really nice place.

M3PqRDKKlq0OYEsjA_CcZQ.text: I really enjoyed this great take on modern British cuisine on my last night in London. It has an upscale yet casual vibe. We wanted to find a great steak place where we wouldn't have to get too dressed up.  I had the vegetable tart while my husband had a rib eye steak. The place is tucked into an alley but is pretty spacious inside.

AT5c8l-OItvctbWHzNlyHg.text: Just off Covent Garden, at the bottom of Langley Street (a New York-style alleyway, only lacking subway steam and a nunchuck weilding gang) sits Hawksmoor Seven Dials. Just as you get to the bottom of the alley, when you think there couldn't possibly be any kind of thriving business, save one of the less than salubrious establishments Soho is famed for, let alone one of London's pre-eminent and widely praised meat restaurants there it is. This is one of London's worst kept secrets, and a meat shrine at which first timers and regulars alike, worship. The heavy, black wooden doors swing open to reveal a low lit reception, and a bevy of Maître ds efficiently deal with coats, bags and lead you down to the bar for drinks and a wait until your table is ready. It's dark, luxurious and just the sort of place to gain the reputation it has. The scene is set for Burger wars. The classic Hawksmoor burger vs the Kimchi burger. Whilst the classic burger fought well, there are a couple of technical errors in style that let it down  the bun disintegration, the raw red onion, the dry triple cooked chips. 8.5/10 The Kimchi burger is the clear winner on the night  great composition, complementary toppings and a great smokey, spicy flavour, and the beef dripping chips are pretty special too! 9.5/10 It's definitely on of the Best Burgers in London: hamburger-me.com/2011/12…

1AStu9cutVM2LeSDdBrMmg.text: Excellent steak, great atmosphere, I'd recommend the beef dripping chips and plum pudding ribs. If you like steak it's a must and good value to boot.

NSw-lpeGKmPeFE_Tu4XiSQ.text: Visited the hawksmoor recently with fellow members of our London Steak club, we had high expectations, it didnt let us down. Having toured most steak restaurants in London now as a group of 18 guys there is little we havent tried but the Hawksmoor raised the bar. We were given the private room (purely luck!) to dine in and then were shown a limited steak menu (we had been told about this in advance). Basically they bought out 5 or 6 plates of varying sizes and cut quality steak and placed on table for us to sample. Sides were very very good and the meat didnt draw one poor comment. The bar area is a little on the small side but service was very good. The surprsing but yet very posiitve thought of the evening was the mix of clients, the norm is 95% men, but this was more 40/60% which created a far more balanced atmosphere. Booking is essentail as they were turning people away on the door and we had booked 3 weeks in advance. Highly recommend, will be back! My only concern is that it may go a little like Goodmans (it got so busy due to success the quality appears to have suffered).. I hope they keep up the wonderful work though!

5EAroblUuLYcEi4AIJfjWg.text: The food? The drink? The atmosphere? Hawksmoor Steak and Cocktail house has it all. And more. The Seven Dials branch, is located opposite Pineapple Studios, about 5 minutes walk from Covent Garden tube. It's well known for its British meat, supplied by the North York Moors butchers, the Ginger Pig, and for how they cook it simply over charcoal. We got a whiff of delicious charred meaty goodness as we approached the understated entrance doors of the converted brewery, which itself is steeped in brilliant steak related history Its first owner, Alderman Combe, hosted an annual steak supper club back in the 1800's, a members, secret high society sort of affair that catered for those lucky people who preached 'beef and liberty' (hence the fabulous sign on the way down to the bar). I doubt I would have made the list back in the day, but last week, when we were welcomed into the low lit funkily decorated cellar bar by friendly laid back staff who seemed to wear whatever what they liked, I felt like the place was on the casual side of special, minus any of ponce you can get in some London places. The restaurant is partitioned from the bar and still retains some stunning architectural features including a vaulted brick ceiling and huge cast iron columns. If you don't fancy a full blow out meal, the bar area is open for their booze and the famous Kimchi burgers (a traditional Korean dish of fermented vegetables  for more info go have a read of some reviews by Eat Like a Girl, Young&Foodish, Going with my Gut). The cocktail menu is HUGE and ranges from both classic drinks to down right eccentric concoctions, including Juleps, Tweaked tikis, Punches and Cups and Bridging drinks, a concept for those Victorian young men who had nothing to do after lunch other than drink cocktails and wait until dinner time came round. Shame. Feeling like I wanted to find out exactly what those crazy kids were enjoying so much, I went for the Bridging drink 'Champagne Charlie', a mix of gin, lemon juice and homemade seasonal fruit syrup (blood orange), charged with champagne. Absolutely delicious, sweet and bubbly, yet with the underlying dryness of gin. My boyfriend had the Boulevardier which was a very manly bourbon based cocktail, but unfortunately it was missing the bourbon-soaked cherry promised on the menu, he didn't seem to mind though. We weren't rushed into the restaurant at all, but went through from the bar when we were ready, a nice and relaxing touch. Unfortunately we couldn't sit on our original table next to the wine cellar because the legs were wobbly and there was a brick that looked like it was about to fall out of the ceiling (dangerous much?), so we got moved to a new section with a waiter who was absolutely hilarious. We swiftly made bets with him on when the brick was going to drop. Probably quite bad taste in hindsight, but he continuously made us laugh whilst providing flawless service. We decided to go for starters. I had read A LOT about the Tamworth Belly Ribs, there was no way I wasn't going to try them. And they didn't disappoint. Left on the bone, they were tender, juicy, sweet and sticky. I could have eaten them all over again with their charcoal bbq flavour and crunchy red cabbage. Actually incredible. Mike had the bone marrow and slow cooked onions and he loved them. Spreading the marrow and onions on thick chunky bread (of which there wasn't quite enough), he oohed and aahed at every mouthful. For me, the presentation was a bit much but the flavour was all there. The rich meaty marrow and sweet onions was served in the bone. I drunkenly said to the waiter as we chatted after the course that they were 'boney in the look' at which he broke into huge laughter and informed us that he'd once been dumped for much the same reasonahem. On to the mains. Well, we could't fit everything onto the table despite not ordering greens (shame on me). We went for the Porterhouse as I've never tried one, a T-Bone steak consisting of two cuts of beef, fillet (tenderloin) and shortloin. I also really wanted to get our waiter to cross our 900g portion off the chalk board which the team use to monitor how much of what is left. The simple things! The meat was heavenly. Smokey, tender, full of flavour and rich meaty juices. Sliced in the kitchen, there were a couple of bits that were a little bit overcooked, a shame when you pay such a premium, but overall it was fantastic. Alongside we chomped down on what are truly the kings of all chips, fried in beef dripping, crunchy, fat, fluffy and undeniably unhealthy, we dunked them into an order of the stilton hollandaise sauce which was tart yet deep and creamy, and we pretty much didn't speak until we were all done. Feeling very fat and very satisfied, what would any sensible couple do? Call it a night and make sure you catch the last tube home. But no, we had to have the sticky toffee pudding, and I'm so glad we did. Our waiter bought it over and gave us a tuneful and very happy

YKhhuGm7c6gAb-0QrMekFQ.text: I went to Hawksmoor the week after it opened in Seven Dials, quite by co-incidence. The steak was absolutely first class and the service was top-notch. Friendly and informal, it was a superb experience. However, I've since been back and it's suffered a bit in its popularity. The meat is still very good, but not quite as good as it once was  you feel as though the busyness of the restaurant has affected the pride and quality that the chefs dedicate to the meat, which in all fairness, is still very good. The service is a little rushed, and the wine list has become (in my uneducated eyes) rather average. For a restaurant that has a wide range of wines, £50 for a very basic Malbec is simply too much. As I've said, the atmosphere here is still good and the food is still very good  the fillets and sides especially  it still feels like a fairly special experience, but it's a lot less special than it once was.

CezAWaDLoAqv70u2BfuSMQ.text: The roast with the most From their first location in Spitalfields, Hawksmoor have peddled top-end steaks perfectly prepared, proving along the way that if you can do something perfectly you can charge as much as you want and people will pay. The first location's exposed brickwork and dark wood speak to the New York approach they take with their meat, a Smith and Wollensky come Quality Meats combination  and long a winning combination for them, albeit one in a slightly cramped East End location. The Seven Dials / Covent Garden location is new, but reminiscent of the first location, although a clear improvement upon it. Gone is the lack of space  from the start, the high-ceilinged entrance hall let's you know that you're in for something big. The staircase leading down into the restaurant is wide and gentle, setting your expectations for the proportions of the experience to come. The cocktail bar is a low-lit, high-stooled experience in anticipation. The cocktail list is substantial, inventive, and not as pricey as it could be. The cocktails themselves are everything they should be, entirely satisfactory, and a great match with the smells from the dining room proper and the dishes that whisk past on waiters' trays. The dining room itself is an old brewery, and exposed red brick, with a high arched brick ceiling, supported on massive iron pillars. Whilst entirely without windows, the indirect lighting is such that you couldn't care less. There are relatively few establishments where you don't feel like you're underground, or at least where you don't care a bit about it. This is definitely one exception. Our visit to Hawksmoor was for their highly affordable roast, but resisting ordering one of their fantastic steaks was an effort, as was resisting one of the many starters. How filling could half a dozen oysters be after all? Maybe we could share a small Chateaubriand on the side with our roast? And whilst we clearly couldn't, and would have made very little headway against it, I do wish we'd tried anyway. The roast itself arrived on a plate the size of a small table, with the single slice of meat itself taking up most of the plate. About as thick as a thumb, and as red as a slapped cheek, the meat was tender, juicy, and everything you'd hope from such beef experts as Hawksmoor. More impressive yet, the rest of the roast was as exceptional  the cabbage full-bodied, the Yorkshire pudding crispy on the outside and doughy on the inside. The gravy was rich, whilst the carrots and roasted onion melted in the mouth. The unexpected roasted head of garlic was beautifully delicate in flavour. The only quibble I had was with the potatoes, an unfortunate combination of too tough on the inside and not crunchy enough on the outside  but even this was barely noticeable in the context. Hawksmoor has a fine selection of desserts, with more than a hint towards a boarding school inspiration  blancmange, ice-cream sundaes, toffee pudding, etc. Whilst the few we had were delicious, and there was a wide enough range of alternatives to appeal to most tastes, it is a rare slip of the veil of sophistication. The service was, with a few exceptions, ideal  at once relaxed and attentive. The beers  sourced from a few select micro-breweries  were full of flavour, and more than strong enough for the  pint glasses they were served in. The wine list was predictably extensive, and not something we even scratched the surface of. The after-dinner spirits were inventive, and as far as the rums went were a revelation. Best of all, for what is otherwise a high-end restaurant, the meal was surprisingly affordable. Highly recommended.
